author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok, so that's a quick summary of the four main types of comp. My suggestion is to pick one model from each category. One and only one. Forget the rest for a while. Start trying it in various places to get a feel for what it does well and how you can use it to shape sounds, to serve the song. The actual plug you choose matters much less than the intrinsic characteristic of the category

Last thought, 99% percent of what I see online in the form or tutorials etc re compression is nonsense, even from some very good friends of mine. Parallel compression for example can be wonderful, but using it as the only workflow on everything for *religious* reasons is just plain silly

Take your time and spend a week with your chosen plug in from each category. Maybe ask here for examples of different styles in real records, Jimmy Pages' acoustic guitars for example. You'll get a sense for it over a little while

OK, QC time over

Good luck!


@Slow Hand please feel free to edit this to tighten it up

author: cian riordan
content:
Just finished mixing my 200th song this year... just... wild! I've had great years before, but this one felt like the true intersection of hard work, strategy, and full on luck. 

Ten years ago I would have looked at this metric and scoffed — somebody 'phoning it in'... but I really did my best to give everything I had on each and every mix... maybe even to my own detriment. There are dear friends in my circle lapping me (Jon, Lars, etc) with their numbers but still,  this is a big milestone as a mixer. 

I’d be remised to not acknowledge the community here and the part it played in having filling the sails with information and inspiration. We all know it can turn for the worst next year, but for now… it’s good. And you guys and the conversations we had here all had a hand in it.

Cheers!

author: chrissorem
content: Shawn likes to paint himself into corners that most people would jump ship. I’ve seen him work himself out of them and come up with the great and unusual results. He’s extremely clever and has a natural punk rock approach to things. I’ve watched him mix numerous times and left thinking I could never make anything sound good in that room or with that approach but he’s managed to figure it out. It’s not always fast or easy but it’s always unique whether you like it or not. He’s been a huge inspiration to me and a constant reminder that we are making art not products.  I’d like to see more engineers following their own instincts and spending less time looking at what everyone else is doing.

author: philbarnes
content:
Whenever I recommend this discord to someone, it's followed up with the comment that you're interacting with people who are actually making records. Not YouTube producers. Not "download my e-book" guys. This space is a rare resource and a gift in the world we work in, and it's not always going to confirm your opinion. I don't post every day because I don't always have something to say or to add value, but I do gain a beautiful new perspective on a subject from reading through here at least a few times a week that I wouldn't have had the thought of without this space.

If you're gonna go after this job for real, you're gonna have the craziest shit thrown at you from clients, collaborators, peers and heroes that you've ever heard. 

Your feelings will not be protected when you operate in this industry at a professional level. 

So, learning to take it on the chin and ask "what is there to learn here?" in a moment you're challenged is what will make you grow and be resilient. 

I just re-printed a stem an hour ago for a background vocal I fucked up "fixing" the timing of in the chorus. The client was incredibly direct and insensitive of my feelings about it, and if I hit them back to argue what was "technically correct" based on the grid and subdivisions I was looking at, and why I was right, they wouldn't care. They wanted it different, so I saw it through their lens of how they wrote the part and corrected it to deliver for the artist. And you know what? That result was better than my feeling of what was "technically correct." They were right. A beautiful reminder to serve the song rather than to check the box. 

The older I get the more I equally trust my taste and remain open to learning something based on new information. Adopting that mindset will only serve you in the process of experimentation of self and collaboration with others.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Man. I am loving the De-emphasis section on Tupe. It lets you squeeze so much saturation out of a signal without driving things too hard. 

First, you drive your signal to the point where the loudest part starts to break up, then you use the de-emphasis to subtract that frequency from the saturation circuit and then you push the gain up even harder until you're on the edge of breakup again. Wash, rinse, repeat. 

What you end up with is a signal that's evenly saturated across the entire frequency range instead of only having the loudest parts treated, because they're all hitting the saturation at roughly the same level. This thing is amazing. It's the sound that I've been searching for for soooo long.

You have the capability to do the thing that will take your life in music about ten steps forward but you’re stuck reading about different types of compression. Your work is good. Let it be good. I PROMISE YOU you will learn FAR more by releasing your first track, and get so much better, than you will handling it like you are now.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
imho, a lot of the vocals I'm hearing from younger record makers are sounding heavily  processed in the same way. "Lack of dynamics" doesn't really explain it because people think of dynamics as dynamic range compression. It's more that everyone is chopping, clip gaining, and RXing to an evenness that softens and linearizes performances. 

These tools work beautifully when shitty mic technique makes things boomy, or there's a few weird ss's on the pre-hyped TLM mic through the focusrite pre.

But it sounds like most people who learn the tools are overusing them like crazy. 

I'm trying these days to get off the details and try as much macro-mixing as possible. When I let performances breathe in their imperfections, I find that I'm drawn in more as a listener.

"Music is the space between the notes". 
-Claude Debussy

"Music is the space between RX moves." 
-Ruairí (probably)

author: Oli J
content: I’d say it’s a combination of things. Arrangement, balance and eq are two most obvious. I’m often looking for bright but not harsh. Other tools worth checking out are soothe, pro-mb (multi band compression to tame those highs) and I sometimes find tape simulation or drive can help. Saturn 2 is a great tool for this too. Feel free to send me a mix where you’re at and I can try and shed some light on a couple of things that might help.

author: philbarnes
content: If you get too into the weeds with a shit-ton of plugins, don't be afraid to start it over with just a single EQ and compressor. I surprise myself with how often a break and reset gets me to a better vocal mix in a fraction of the moves.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Working on a mix today, we’ve been grinding on it a lot, a song recorded in lets say a “less than ideal way”. First half of the first verse just wasn’t right on the vocal. Threw everything I had it. Compressor after compressor, soothes, spectres, automations, eq before and after, still not quite right. Took off all the compressors. 1 eq. Readjusted the levels. Perfect. 

Sometimes the best thing you can do is get perspective and be willing to undo everything you’ve done.

author: cian riordan
content: Had a fun moment today where I'm mixing this retro-ey sounding tune for a band and I was really struggling to get the rhythm section to lock in and feel really warm and pillowy. I did a number on the drums but just couldn't get the low end to sync between the two. I ended up sending the mono bass to two mis-matched outboard compressors. They're totally un-linked and I just matched them by ear and wow... sounds so fucking good. Each one is grabbing and doing it's thing and it's *mostly* adding up to mono but gives real life when things momentarily lean left or right. Reminds me of a drum setup photo today where some of the mics were mis-matched and that's just honest-to-god so OK most of the time.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Sunday reminder: don’t apply global eq on a track to fix one thing on the track.

I’ve been kicking around this mix and there was a resonance in some of the vocal bits, so I had an eq or 2 on the track to even them out. Maybe some multiband. And after an hour of frustration I bypassed everything and it sounded better (also your reminder to bypass). I went in and just printed some specific eq in the two or three words that were bothering me, and a little ess editing, and it was all much better. (Also, don’t be afraid to start from zero again,, especially if you find yourself editing an edit).

author: Deleted User
content:
@rawssx Sometimes you ask question about A but get B as an answer, and a lot of times- that’s because there is no good answer to the question and B is the best answer to address the question in a holistic way. 

These are things I found that helped me grow and learn from folks that are willing to give. 

1) Knowing what questions to ask is also a skill. This is because  knowing what to ask comes from experience. It is difficult to know what to ask if there are no accumulation of context and situations to consider. It takes frustration and trial/error over situations to know what questions to ask when it comes to mixing. Whatever information or tips are useless without understanding the why. And it may still be useless even if you do understand the why- and that is because “why” is the part that matters, not how it’s done or what is done. “Why” is at the center of all of those things.

2) Be open to the answer B - try to listen and see what B has to offer. Try it out even if you disagree. You can form your opinion once you have done that. But remember, hold a loose grip on opinions- sometimes knowing more or experiencing more things can change your world view and the willingness to shift from that can make or break your growth

author: bobby k
content: shifting gears for a sec - something i've been a big fan of this year is duplicating a lead vocal and stripping back any compression / dynamic control to a secondary track with no output, then putting any reverb sends on that track instead of the main ldv. this saves pretty much any instinctual reverb automation "throws" and the such because the vocals natural dynamic is lighting up the reverb the same way it would in real life. it now strikes me how odd and unnatural it would sound to have a vocal hitting the reverb about as hard during soft moments as during dynamic moments. unfortunately there are many cases where this is simply not possible as i'm already starting with a heavily compressed vocal. maybe i'm late to this, but anybody else do this or something similar with success?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
@BoozleBAM This is a GREAT question, and having read the whole convo twice I don't think it was really answered. Honestly I probably won't be able to answer it either, but here are some thoughts in no particular order

First the usual caveat, I'm not a mixer and I haven't mixed a record in a decade. But I did record and mix for 20 years before that and followed the whole arc from beginner not understanding compression, to pro finding my way and getting to own or use all of the baller dream hardware. All that to say I have a lot of empathy for where you are at with it. These are not definitive statements, just aspects to think about..

1) First something of a hot take that I don't see represented online. IMO compression often makes an individual instrument sound "worse". If you play and record something like drums well or acoustic guitar well, a compressed version will often sound *less real* and less vital. So why in the world would we do it???

- The first reason is that we mostly don't care about how individual instruments sound, we care about the whole song. Often a compressed sound will play nicer in an arrangement than something dynamic, real and recorded in a "documentarian" way

- The second reason is a trade off that isn't often spoken about. Compressed instruments often translate better into the wild. Take a beautiful, dynamic, real sounding, hifi & documentarian recording of say upright bass, drums and acoustic guitar. Listen in your studio in great monitors and it's a dream. Now go to Target and play it in mono on the overhead speaker on a busy saturday.....it just won't survive ... the song gets lost. Or drive with your window open, or cook dinner with the AC on etc etc.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
I am super nerdy / obsessive about single coil hum, here are the tricks I’ve found:
- all my single coil guitars have been shielded - you should get a pickguard shield and also get the cavities shielded with copper. Puisheen on YouTube (mikes guitar bar) has a great tutorial. This will cost about 10$ per guitar and make a big difference.
- computer monitors can be a big culprit, especially older Apple Cinema displays. You kinda have to right facing direction with the guitar, usually 90 degrees from the screen. Think of single coils like figure 8 microphones, you want the screen in the null.
- ground loops can also be a big problem. I had this buzz going on DI guitars and most of my unbalanced synths - turns out one of my midi interfaces was creating a ground loop, you can get a ground lifting usb adapter. In my case I have balanced power at the studio and different phases (not sure if that the correct English term) but basically any USB hub is now on a different circuit then audio stuff and that removed a lot of buzz. On that topic, if you are using pedals make sure you have a good isolated power supply.
- last but not least: a proper guitar setup will help, if your pickups are too low, the signal to noise ratio will decrease. That being said I think I kinda like my pickup height a little lower than standard but that is just a taste thing.

author: cian riordan

author: cian riordan
content: Amazing what a slammed pair of 1176s can do at 5-10% on a mix. Not a prescription for most things, but when it works it’s great.

author: cian riordan
content: Hell yea. I'd start by having a relatively dry kit in a relatively dry space. The snare is tuned up pretty high but somewhat dead... avoiding the big 150-300hz fundamental that a lot of indie records are chasing these days. It's a very Nigel Godrich-y compression sound which is -- not really the sound of compression on the snare mic, but more on the kit as a whole. You'll notice that the whole kit, cymbals included, is really getting pressed up against whatever compression is happening. And to make that work, the drummer is playing very lightly... even on the heavier chorus sections. I'd probably start with a pair of 1176s or an 1178 strapped across the kit... medium attack and fast release (or heavier handed on a parallel bus) and you'll get that great snap from such a light touch.

author: Adam Thein
content: Pretty sure I stole this trick somewhere from someone but repeating here cause it's been saving me time getting reverbs slotted but basically put spectre in 100% wet and move a band around after a reverb to find a good little slot for the vocal EQ while also controlling the dynamics a bit with the saturation and then you can flip through the styles to find a good texture that works in that range. author: bobby k
content:
Mind if I ramble? I'm working on what is probably the most challenging mix I've done this year. I've been at my first pass for close to 2 weeks, and have probably started it over 4 times. For context, it's a very dense country rock song with like 80-90 tracks, heavy heavy buss processing, many layers hitting exceptional stages of compression and saturation. The most challenging part is that, despite my philosophical differences from the producer's template, the rough mix really works. Anytime I try to strip it back, import my template, do my own thing, make the mix fit into my "mixing philosophy", it just falls apart. I've considered stemming it out with Bounce Factory through his template to then put the tracks into my template, but that would be a zero sum game I can already expect to lose. 

Ultimately I've had to shift my perspective of wondering "why am I here?" I'm learning that my role is not to run this song through some proprietary process I take pride in, but to simply just help them reach the finish line by trying to understand and continue within the process they've already deeply baked this song through. I've found that I can apply my perspective while setting my "process" aside, and explore what small tweaks or decisions I *can* make that get us the last couple % we might be missing. Any previous approach I've tried I already know would result in a 10+ revision nightmare trying to get back to the original magic of the rough.

And on the interpersonal front, I've decided against sharing any of this struggle with the artist. Maybe the mix that gets approved of the 4 that I've done is the one I spent 30 minutes on, but the many hours of me feeling like I'm "failing" on the other 3 passes were needed to understand that this track only needed 30 minutes of my time. Excuses don't get us to the finish line. 

What has been your experience in these situations?

author: bobby k
content: i learned something new about Soothe yesterday that I found valuable - the "soft" vs "hard" mode doesn't affect ratio so much as it affects how the threshold behaves. Soft has what I understand to be a "smart" floating threshold that kind of rides the signal, versus hard is closer to a fixed threshold (and I believe depth then affects the ratio and threshold in it's own way). So, if you were trying to zone in on a frequency that only occasionally rears it's head, hard mode with a lower depth will be generally more accurate and not affect the other parts of the audio nearly as much. I don't like using Soothe on sibilance, but I actually found it quite effective after learning this by setting it to hard mode with a very broad "sharpness".

author: cian riordan

author: sethearnest
content:
The main stereo verb swimming the whole time has a lot of pre-delay on it and it doesn’t have any of the high freq info in it. A dark, pre-delayed verb will tuck behind a vocal well and allow the verb to be noticed but not push back the vocal b/c the vocal itself is bright and “dry” for 50ms or 80ms or however long the pre-delay is, both of which keep things “close” to our ears. There also doesn’t seem to be any center of that verb—it’s all wide, so that helps keep the vocal clear. There’s a mono dark delay throw happening here and there, too, which gives some good front to back depth. 

Also sounds like some compression or ducking (or however they did it) on the verb that opens up between the lyric spaces, so yet another thing that helps keep the vocal dry-but-also-wet feeling.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve got thoughts here on this artisan vs technician topic. 

When writing songs, I find that inspiration can’t really be counted on to show up when you want it to. But not working when you don’t feel inspired leads to atrophied creative muscles, which is paradoxical, but true. It’s why the saying “the muse finds you working” is a thing. 

So what I found when choosing to write despite not being inspired, was that that’s the only time I could work on the *craft*. Inspiration is a slave driver. 

This held true over into the recording world for me as well. When I was trying to capture something in my head I was a slave to it, but when I’m trying to capture something in someone else’s head, I’m merely curious and experimental. And *that’s* when I learned the craft. Mixing, recording, producing, etc. 

The TL;DR of it all is I think being a service oriented technician is a major part of growing into your artistry. At least it was for me.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: Any of you all ever used the Gaffel Synced Band Splitter? I was treated to a bit of a real life MWTM with Chris Coady last night (super kind guy) and he was showing me this plugin to mix a big pop vocal sound. He duplicated the lead vocal twice to have three tracks and had this plugin as the first insert on each track, split into three bands for each channel, low vocal, mid vocal, high end vocal. The plugin auto syncs the band settings in all instances whenever you adjust a band. He was saying Serban uses this plugin and does that exact thing on some songs. After treating each track with some eq/comp/saturation the vocal sounded really big but balanced. And it’s like $60 so I think I’m going to have to grab it. Probably could do this with other plugins but I appreciated the auto-syncing function and also didn’t notice any weird phase issues which you could maybe run into trying to create the bands by hand?

author: tomtom

Turn the conversation to “conceptual technique”.. what are the big picture things that you wish you knew earlier? Things that’ll open up your ears? Big pillars for me were connecting arrangement to mixing, glue vs contrast, LCR awareness, front to back awareness… dynamic range, harmonics vs fundamental… how shit really makes you feel…stuff like that. The basics are always being applied.. author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’ve been staunchly against clip-gaining for “compression” on vocals until today.

Tracked a vocal yesterday without compressing on the way in for the first time in forever. Clip gaining into ITB compression ended up sounding like good mic technique. Clip gaining *after* compression just sounds like… bad volume rides?

author: Adam Thein
content:
Something that resonated with what @BatMeckley said an hour ago - “don’t be afraid to start from zero again”

Especially while you are learning maybe trying a few approaches is worth the extra time when there is not a deadline you are up against.

I’ve had a few mixes this year where I’m toward the end of the mix and have been living with a vocal chain for a while and just pull everything off it only to realize it just needed a little more top end and a touch of automation here and there when I had 8 plugins on it before.  That’s maybe an exaggeration but the idea is lean into what’s great about digital mixing - save a version, try something new.  If you are versioning there is always a way back to where you were.  Repetition and experimentation will help you find ways to solve problems and speed things up for you down the road.

author: popaganda.

author: Matt Huber
content: Saturn 2, warm tape mode, single band. Pull LF back 1.8 to flatten and then trim in back -24 and output up 24. The drive knob then becomes a really gentle saturator. It can be very subtle and very nice for coloration and density.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
**VCA compressors** - examples would be the SSL bus or channel compressors, or the DBX160. These have less instrinsic tone or color from distortion etc but grab and shape envelopes in a very particular way that can be really useful. Punchy would be a decent overall descriptor
 
**Opto** LA-2A, CL-1B etc. These tend to have fast attacks and a release that starts fast and then slows down which can give them a lovely forgiving character on certain instruments. They often come with tube line amps and with that distortion from the tubes and transformer which can add body. They can add a kind of glow or richness to a sound, holding it in place in a gentle musical way

**FET** 1176, Spectrasonics 610, Compex, Distressor etc. These can have very fast attack, and a release that can be varied from very fast and explosive to slower. The FET itself causes quite a bit of distortion which gives them a spanky and very alive kind of character. They often have a "smaller sound" that focusses things, grabs attention and brings it to the front of a mix

**Vari-Mu** Fairchild, Manley Varimu, BG2, Magic Death Eye etc. These us a tube as the actual gain reduction element and tend to have a low and varying ratio, attack and releases that are musically linked, a gentle knee and often add tone and weight becuase of the low order harmonics they add. They can be a little "slow" and sludgy sometimes but when they are right they are really right

-

author: cian riordan
content: With bass, I'm usually compressing the bass and getting the DI pumping how I like, then bringing the level up in to the -4 to -6 dbFS or so. Then I'll make a mono, post fader send to a mono aux with sansamp. I'll send a healthy level then start by adding a little bit of drive, then playing with the buzz, punch, and crunch to fold in the distortion -- but thinking of it like an EQ. Using it to fill in the harmonic gaps that aren't cutting through when the drums and guitars are going. Very rarely touching the high/low eq on the right.

author: cian riordan

My rule of thumb is lower voicing tend to occupy center-mid, and the higher voicings out wide to create a wider spread. Like if I was making a Queen record, I'd probably stick to your approach because the arrangement would be airtight -- and LCR would work great. But if I was fucking with some indie pop producer that has a boner for a million tracks in his session, then it's warfare and I'm just trying to place things where they work.

author: BatMeckley

I have questions.
Why are you doing multiple proq3 next to each other? (As someone who accidentally found themself doing the same thing). I understand maybe, pre compressor/post compressor… but a bunch in a row?

Also, eq is rarely a victimless crime. Each point you add is going to add a resonance or a phase shift or what not. I try to get away with doing the least amount possible, while also trying to not be afraid of “doing what it takes”. What I usually find is I’ll go overboard initially, and then start bypassing things to make sure that my changes were actually making my things better overall, and that I didn’t lose the forrest for the trees, hurting the big pictures chasing after something insignificant

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nowadays I am committing tracks sooner and sooner in the process. It's partly a result of me feeling more assured in my choices, and partly me aiming to reduce the complexity of my sessions as I proceed through them. I hate large sessions.

Nothing is more demoralizing than that feeling of being in the final mix and still auditioning new kick drum samples at the final hour. I had a production/mix like that last year and it drove me crazy because nothing felt locked in. I had no fixed point in the mix to work from or to build off of.

Nowadays whenever I think to myself "This _ feels great and like a finished record" I will immediately commit it to audio to prevent myself from unraveling the work I've already done.

I'm the type of person that if I saw a channel with twelve plugins on it I get suspicious and start paring it back to see if I can create the sound with less processing. Sometimes this is the right move, but if I start tweaking the compressor in the 2nd plugin slot that's downstream of 8 more plugins that's a good way to de-stabilize the entire sound you've built up. Committing sooner prevents me from unraveling too much of the audio.

author: BatMeckley
content: Make a new duplicate snare track. Gate the hell out of it. Also band pass it to roughly the frequency that’s bumming you out. Use that as your side chain key. You can bring the gain up or down to affect the threshold. On soothe use the high and low pass filter to further narrow down the offending frequency, and then use a bell eq and raise or lower it at 10k to affect the threshold. (That’s essentially soothes threshold setting). You got this.

author: chrissorem
content:
It seems like you might be spending to much time in the micro nuances of mixing. (Easy to do that)  try a new approach. Make quick moves and jump to something else, if the kick is too….. it will remind you everytime you listen. Try  to step back and listen to your mixes like a ME. Is there too much or not enough of a certain frequency range?  Then dive back into the micro move adjust and move on. This helps  you stay in the flow and to not get lost  in the weeds.  In my experience the music tells you most of what you need to know. Tempo has a huge effect on how the low end can work. Density often determines how midrange and upper mid/ high freq should work.  The elements in the mix should be serving particular roles and that informs where things should sit and ultimately equal how it makes you feel. I don’t think very much when I mix but I react to what’s in front of me . 
The more you do this the more this will lock in. Another thing that comes to mind, is sometimes if I’m feeling like something isn’t right I’ll do a save as or In your example I’ll mute the kick and duplicate it and start from scratch and see if I can beat it. Sometimes order of operations can lead you down certain paths and as other elements enter the original moves might not being working

author: cian riordan
content:
So for all the mixing nerds here, thought you mind find this interesting. For the past 6 months or so I've embraced the idea of having an analog mix buss. I've always strayed away from it in lieu of keeping things fluid for easy recalls. However, since I've been doing 100% of my mixing in this studio and this gear probably isn't goin anywhere, I've been more comfortable leaning on a hardware chain with (what I think are) great results. 

First, I'm going into an old UTA Unfairchild. This was the first model that came out with the 6BC8 tubes instead of the current 6386 tubes. I always preferred the older model and was lucky to snatch one when Barefoot kicked the bucket. I'm not actually doing any compression, I've just got gain at unity and signal passing through. The second stage is a pair of UTA MPEQ-1's. I *thought* that I was doing a high shelf boost starting at 8.3k going into a LPF @ 22k. 

I've really, really been enjoying the sound of this. I notice a little midrange clarity from the unfairchild and I find the additive high end on the buss is much more musical than boosting individual elements.

author: Eric Martin
content:
Just from the hour of watching JC mix yesterday I understand a little better how things get “loud” in his mixing. He uses peak limiters and clippers everywhere, so nothing has a chance of peaking out from where he placed it. That’s in effect trimming all the Attack of an instrument but not really messing with the decay sustain or release because with a peak limiter it’s acting so fast that you can use it to manipulate a sound without it drastically changing the other aspects of it ADSR in synth world works the same in all audio. A clipper does the manipulation for “saturation” to get the desired grit that we might have gotten in yesteryear from things like tubes tape and transformers.

I think that it’s likely a smart fast and easy way to get a result like JC is looking for where it’s loud and sounds open still. Because you can’t really hear the peak limiting like you can hear a compressor doing 4:1 compression. Also know JC has a 1k “handicap” as he calls it on his mix bus, pulling out a few db and he is using the spectral shaper from 1-6k to tame harshness on the mix bus. (Don’t do this just because he does) These are things he’s added because it helps him get to his desired result faster, and when you mix one or two songs a day everyday for years you’re going to develop “tricks” or “handicaps” or whatever you want to call them to help you get to your desired result.

Learn everything you can about mixing if that’s what you want to do, and use only the things you try that YOU like, not because someone else makes work you like, your mileage may vary

author: Slow Hand
content: Since you're trying to get more juice out of Pro-L2, I would give this guide a quick read. The biggest takeaway for me is that the Attack knob on Pro-L2 is counterintuitive and dialing the attack time all the way back to 10s will get you less distortion and a feeling of more attack and transient (while retaining the same limiting): https://www.jonathanjetter.com/blog/fabfilter-prol2-timeconstants

author: ALXCPH
content:
this is answer might not be the most exciting.

Actual Separation does not come from EQ, Compression and Saturation. These are just tool to help manipulate a sound into how you want it to sound. 

Separation comes from Arrangement. If you have a Piano and a Guitar playing full chords in the same octave, you'll never get good sounding separation, no matter how much you try and manipulate the sound.
Sounds are made from a fundamental and certain overtones/harmonics. If they overlap, then they overlap, even if you add a random eq boost on each sound some Freqs apart, because someone on youtube did that. (not that you can't do it, and it wont work)
But Instead of removing good sounding parts of a sound forcing them to fit together(whatever that even means at this point), arrange the parts so they naturally fit together with separation. This way you'll be able to act more, creatively and instinctively on how you want the sounds to sound while mixing, instead of fitting a triangle into a circle. As the good old saying says, it starts at the source, for the best results. 

Fx, in a typical jazz band, often a Bass will play roots on 1 & 3,  a piano will of then play the root and 5th an octave above that, and a guitar could play the 3rd and 7th, and together all the instruments make big full chords while also having their own space. this way there is now plenty of room for a singer or a Sax player to do its thing and not worry to much about cutting through a dense mix.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man it goes both ways- sometimes if you’ve got problem frequencies or too much bottom a compressor will react to the wrong things, and depending on what you’re using to compress there may be problem frequencies imparted. I wouldn’t be afraid to eq both before and after compression/saturation. 

There’s no limit on the amount of plugins you can put on a vocal chain, so often I approach it with a lot of things doing a little bit at a time, just adding or subtracting things I’m looking for.

But if more freedoms is stressing you out, try this approach. 
Add a comp in the second slot
See what jumps out at you, and then decide if you need to eq what’s going into the comp, or just what’s coming out of it.
Subtractive eq 
De essing 
More compression/saturation
More subtractive eq/de essing 
Additive eq 
Any final touches (limiting, saturation, de essing, etc)
Fx 

Use as many plugs as you think you need to. 

Then go back and disable everything, adding them back one at a time to make sure everything you’ve done is helpful on a fresh listen. 

If you love everything you’ve done but need a little more on the chain, commit and start as if that’s your recorded vocal and go from there.

author: Felix Byrne
content:
ime clip gain the best way for most of those huge jumps in volume
once u get a workflow down it can be very quick (quicker than fucking around with 5 compressors for 15 mins trying to get something that works, or spending the next week banging your head against a wall trying to make it work)

ctrl shift is the layer shortcut for all clip gain stuff
C copies (you can bump something up and then copy that gain move - ie +4dB) and quickly select and paste it onto other notes that need a similar amount
V pastes
X cuts (and also creates a fade between two points!!) - this does reset the copy clipboard tho so usually i will do one pass correcting gain and then another pass doing the fades
up and down arrows or scroll lets you adjust up and down by a certain amount (which you can set in preferences)
E lets you insert a point at the current scroll time
B resets the gain to 0

author: alex_epton
content: You can clip a little bit off before hitting a limiter. It actually makes the limiter sound a little less “spongy” and compressor-y sounding. Sometimes digital recordings have weird suuuuper spiky transients that your dynamics processors can’t deal with without a bunch of artifacts. If you were on a nice board with transformers everywhere that stuff gets clipped off and you don’t even notice…. but who’s got time for that

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i don't know anyone who makes modern records who doesn't compress AT ALL. jon has sometimes said he doesn't compress but 98% of the stuff he mixes has TONS of compression before it gets to him. 

like @Zakhiggins said, i dance between clip gain and dynamic processing when i'm mixing, using both 100% of the time. i adjust them back and forth, back and forth. sometimes undoing one in favor of the other. 

using both tools in tandem makes for much better clarity without killing dynamics. even SUPER compressed modern pop vocals are better with lots of little clip gaining. 

sometimes i use clip gain to raise the level of a word and even things out, but sometimes i use clip gain to reduce level and undo the sound of super compression so it's adds dynamics.

author: cian riordan
content: By this logic, you could argue that any tool in a mixers toolbox is a band aid to a problem created in recording. Compression a bandaid for something recorded too dynamically. HPF a bandaid for something that was incorrectly recorded with too much low end. A Pultec high boost a bandaid for something too dark. Sometimes you get a vocal that has a pokey resonance that happens at 3k and if you try cutting with EQ, it kills the aggressiveness… but if you do it dynamically, it only snags it when the frequency poked 15 dB above where it should.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
If the reverb's there from production and has to stay:

- It doesn't always need to be heard, sometimes can just be felt
- Sometimes it can be drastically EQd
- Sometimes automated so it's clearly audible when there's space for it, and tucked when there isn't
- Sometimes complementary (but different!) mono ambiences panned around maintain more breathing room than a stereo ambience that might blur the center. Tchad Blake is very good at this sort of thing.

If the reverb's coming from me, added in the mix, and it's not working quickly, I'll take a second and consider whether I've been barking up the wrong tree

author: Rollmottle
content: It smears/kneecaps transients in exchange for the small possibility that your master may distort on somebody's playback system somewhere. You could also turn down the limiter gain at which point that possibility of audible distortions in those playback systems diminishes, at which point, you can just turn it off anyways and keep your transients. For most modern music in most modern playback scenarios, none of that will matter and the trade off is not worth it.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
So for this song I was hired to produce and mix it. I got the stems from the demo and did the production in ableton. Then vocals were recut in London and I was sent a Pro Tools session. I always cut and edit in Pro Tools, so I used this session to comp and arrange the new vocals, but then I wanted to just bring it back into ableton and blend with the existing production. So I bounced the vocal from Pro Tools dry  (no verb or delay) but with tuning and some compression and EQ. Then I used some of the demo vocal and some of the new vocal in the final mix.

I'm pretty comfortable committing eq and compression on my vocals (the confidence of years of doing this... ps you should do it more, it's good for the workflow). But if I needed to go back for some reason I could go back to the Pro Tools session. I think I did go back once to remove tuning on an ad lib that was part singing, part talking. 

I'm getting much more comfortable mixing in ableton. The only thing that really sucks about it is that the sessions do tend to slow down when there's TONS of vocals with autotune inserts (the equivalent number of tracks and autotune instances in pro tools does not tax Pro Tools nearly in the same way). So thus far the only way that ableton really works for me to both produce and mix in is if I don't have raw vocals in there. Hence, bouncing from pro tools works best anyway.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
(Incoming self-indulgent ramble that I’ll probably regret on sending - but there’s some sense in it, and I’ve been typing for so long now that I can’t not post it)
 
For sure. Sometimes the mountain analogy doesn’t quite click with me because I feel it infers challenge, met with triumph. 

But I never feel like I’ve triumphed! And the challenges don’t feel specific enough to be “met”, per se. And even if they were, nobody is marking this stuff empirically out of ten (hear me out @BatMeckley 👀).

I produced + mixed a single early on in my bedroom (Rokit 5s, baby!) that attained certain undeniable metrics of success, but listening back, it’s so clear that it did so *in spite* of my (in)competence as a mixer. It still *feels* great, but sonically it’s all over the shop. I’ve since wandered the great valley of intuition-knowledge-intuition, and the only really crucial thing I’ve picked up is that if it *feels* great, the rest is largely (obvs take that lightly) inconsequential. I know this is not a novel thought, especially recently here. But anyway…

Another reason for my certainty about this is that there are so many records I listened to in my teens (pre any recording/mixing/critical listening experience etc) that *felt* amazing and blew my mind then, and still do now - even though now I can step back and hear the abrasive guitars, out of tune everything, etc etc.

All this to say that the reason I don’t ever feel like I’ve triumphed / bested a climb is that in 1/2/5 years from now, I’m going to listen back on my work from today and cringe at the over brightness, the congestion, the brickwall filter ringing at 732Hz 👀, the mixbus compression folding too hard on that downbeat…

author: Edward Rivera
content:
Classic Steve quote:

_ When I first started making records I would sit in front of the console concentrating on the music every second. I found out the hard way that I tended to fiddle with things unnecessarily and records ended up sounding tweaked and weird. I developed a couple of techniques to avoid this, to keep me from messing with things while still paying attention enough to catch problems. For a long time I would read, but it had to be really dry un-interesting stuff. The magazine the Economist was perfect, as were things like technical manuals and parts catalogs. I had a stack of them by the console. It can’t be anything interesting or with a story line like fiction because then you can get engrossed and stop paying attention to the session. It has to be really dull, basically so you are looking for an excuse to put it down and do something else. This has proven to be a really good threshold, so that if anything sounds weird or someone says something you immediately give it your full attention and your concentration hasn’t been ruined by staring at the speakers and straining all day.

Lately I play Scrabble, and it serves the same purpose_

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
A+ advice above. Few small things I'd add:

1. Don't be overly concerned by what you see on the screen. A certain style on a compressor that says "clean" may not actually be. It may have more harmonics than various other styles on the same plugin. Certain meters move faster than others, not all 10ms attack times will actually attack the same, certain GUIs that imply some sort of analog modeling may not actually do so, etc. Just listen and trust your ears.

2. If you can't hear certain aspects right away, that's fine too. You can't force it, don't rush it. Still just listen and trust your ears.

3. I liked compression less when my monitoring was lousy and not suitably dynamic, because everything sounded more compressed than it actually was.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: I loved how they talk about making choices that "sound more like [Billie]". Like they've taken in all the technical crap we all fill our heads with and were really disciplined about making moves that took them in the right direction. The really magical part of what they're doing is knowing, for themselves and Billie/Finneas, what was the right stuff to add/take away. The NOT magical part was how they did it- just instantiating two different LA-2A's and flipping between them and saying "yeah i like that". I do that shit every day, but do I always make the right string of choices one after the other throughout the mix? Probably not. Which tells me I should probably focus more on understanding the intent of the song and less on the exact techniques by which I get there.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Surprise surprise ima jump in with some Brauer bullshit again- zooming out of the vocal for a second, cuz I think the choices you’re talking about making, when made in a vacuum, can lead you to very different places depending on what you’re already hearing when you start adding vox fx. 

The idea is to identify the 2 or 3 things that the brain can actually focus on at any given moment in a song as the leading roles. Song I was on the other day had horns, vocal, and occasionally gtr were leading and everything else was just supporting (either octaves of the same part, rhythmically the same, or pads on keys). So I got those 3 rocking together without worrying about every track, it was easy to identify the kind of space I needed. I wanted it in the same room as the brass, but really forward on the stage. If I’d had the pads up while trying to do this I was always either too wet or too dry and couldn’t find the happy place. The tl;dr is, if you’re struggling to find a satisfying construction of ideas, you may be trying to treat leading and supporting parts as equally important, and you’re challenging your ear to grab what’s really important at that moment. 

Also in Brauer’s template there are a folder of verbs that everything in the session shares including vocals. So you get a sense of cohesion from that, and the vocals have their own folder of delays that are unique to them. That helps create separation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
One habit that I've picked up using Ableton that's really handy is doing all of my volume rides and mute automation with a *utility* plugin. This gives me a few advantages:

1. I can place the rides/mutes exactly where I want in the signal path (into a compressor, before a verb, after a verb, etc)

2. I can easily enable/disable the automation if I want to A/B or simplify while solving another problem.

3. My faders are left solely for global level changes and I can easily mute the channel without mute automation turning it back on/off.

author: Deleted User
content: I like to think of it as these three terms. 1) EQ/Sauce - no predelay or barely any (sometimes I compress it to play with the shape of it too) 2) space - 50 to 80ms (or use mix of reverb with no predelay on a slap with slightly longer delay time) 3) bloom 90-200ms. I usually just put a time delay on it before reverb if I want musically timed reverb, but I personally tend not to go towards that direction very often. I’m also a big throws person so mostly my main reverb that are sent to aux tracks have medium to longer predelay and throws would have shorter predelay. Sometimes it’s the other way around too. I also like to make decisions based on how long I want the vocals to be closeup for before I hear the reverb kick in. Or I also print reverb sometimes and nudge it around in different parts and play with fades if I wanna get really sculpt-y with it. I do this with reverb throws (dups clips to audio tracks rather than sends) more often than send verbs.

author: Eric Martin

author: cian riordan
content: @Zack Hames On second look, this comes off kind of jerk-ey and I didn't meant to just brush off your quest for saturation dominance! I guess what I meant to say is that through the dozens of interviews with Jon and Matt, it's clear that he's averse to using compressors and tends to use saturators more to do the job. While I fuckin' LOVE me some saturators, I honestly don't see the two as interchangeable... they're just two very different tools. One is leveling volume and the other is distorting a waveform to generate harmonics. I think saturators are a great next level tool for people who have wrapped their brains around compression.... but you really need some form of compression on an un-treated vocal. I feel in contemporary music, people are leaning too much on high-end saturation to get things to sound exciting and hyped. If I'm ever using saturators to distort things (which is often), I'm always trying to find some sort of un-distorted high end source to help the ears cling to clarity in the mix. Sometimes, things will distort in a way that will add this clarity -- or even manufacture it. But most of these multi-band saturators are just adding a layer of fuzz to the entire midrange up and the whole mix just ends up sounding hazy. IMO, a great example of modern hip-hop mixing is Mac Miller's Circles. The high end on that record sounds just as exciting as anything else, but it doesn't sound like everything got ran through a buzz saw (shoutout Greg Koller/Jon Brion). Just my 0.02.

As a general rule, pan hard left and right, compress the snot out of them, take out the low end, and i most of the time prefer them brighter so I can hear them. author: NoahNeedleman
content:
IME, generally speaking, considering it’s gonna get mixed again and paired with other live elements, more focus on eq less on compression, very careful with ambiences. (Verbs in an arena are gonna be useless, but using tracks to add depth to the whole mix is a big argument for having them in the first place.) Tight performances, but very careful on 2&4 information cause flams with the live snare will be VERY noticeable, so snare help needs to live either above or below the live snare… 
It’s all about supporting the live elements, so stems from the mixer are rarely as good as audio files from the producer or even better, retracked elements for consistency of sonics from song to song. 
This is where I lean when mixing/recording/compiling live tracks for artists.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Also, we say "there are no rules" a lot. But actually that's not nuanced enough for my taste (and perhaps, this place).

There are many great "rules." Yes, some are dumb and some are wrong, but many of them are worth learning so you know how to break them.

Things like "cut eq before you compress, boost after" is a really great rule. When you learn to do it and to hear it, you learn why it's so important (pulling low end plosives out of a vocal so it doesn't pin the compressor, for example). From there you learn how and when to break it (I like boosting the 200hz-ish body of a live snare drum into a parallel compressor/ saturator to solidify and have control of that frequency range, automate it for fills, etc.).

IMO this is a great "rule," which is great to learn and then break all the time.

author: cian riordan
content: All I would say is do your automation first and get things in the same ballpark before compressing. author: Tristan
content:
Repetition, template, predictability = reliable outcomes. 

It’s as much about gain-staging as it is providing QC’d deliverables. Both inform how you work, and you might tweak your template to make your life easier at the end.

Be a minimalist in plugins, use less complicated routing schemes and mixing techniques - go back to basics and implement more creative approaches as needed. Most sessions of pro level mixers will be 80% the same plugin(s) because they know how they react. If something reacts weirdly, or a meter is going unusually berserk and doesn’t match what they expect to hear, it prompts them to interrogate and make changes if need be - I.e. rogue low end rumble smashing a compressor.

No one single person working at a high level I know works exactly the same, but they have some kind of process in place that works for their brain and business. Some more elegant than others.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- The classic example of compression is to use a fast release with something like a parallel drum buss. As the release lets go and brings up the room gain you get this urgent and explosive energy. When the room is good, and the compression timing is set right it can really make things sound bigger than real life. Remember we're trying to tell a story here, we can't jam the *actual* real power and size of stadium rock drums into that mono speaker at Target but listen to Paradise City and it tells the story pretty well ... our brain does an amazing job of filling in the rest

- The last example is using something like a good tube compressor on vocals. With a nice soft knee and lots of gain reduction we get bring up a bunch of low level and emotional detail, breathy whispery stuff at the end of lines etc that can really help a lyric connect. Often with something like a good tube compressor we get a healthy amount of harmonic distortion too along for the ride which adds weight to the vocal and draws the listeners attention

author: Matt Huber
content:
What Josh said has been super helpful for me. 

Also, an easy thing to forget is level matching. Most tape plugins by default making things a bit louder, so make sure to compensate for that. Oftentimes, after level matching, I feel that a lot of tape plugins can make things come across “smaller” or duller  due to the transient rounding and (sometimes) the saturation. 

But also, sometimes those things are THE vibe for the song.

sam and i were DM-ing separately about this too, but I'm copying a message I shared about why I like to trigger in samples from the same kit/session if anybody cares to chime in... 

*"many different answers to this based on what you're working on but i'll use today's mix on my end as an example. mixing the audio for a live in studio recording of an artist that is quite pop, but tours with a tight band that makes the music much more live. Wanting this to be a hybrid of the two sounds, not a live show and not a spotify release but somewhere in the middle, so I premixed the snare/kick/tom samples and triggered them in. My favorite element for this is that I can work with the overheads in addition to the close mics and sculpt those to fit each drum. For example, the toms I'm blasting the overhead with tape saturation that is giving them a nice airy attack. then when I trigger them in, I'm essentially getting that tone from the overheads without applying that processing to the entire overhead mix (which has loads of cymbals). If most of my snare tone was coming from just close mics, I wouldn't care as much about triggering it would just be more for a consistent sound. but since I can sculpt the overheads so distinctly for each drum, it's making a much bigger impact on the mix to use these samples. additionally, i'm triggering in the kick and snare from the original track, which are kind of pop/electronic sounding, and just blending them in enough to get the attitude of the studio version."*

The amount of times I’ve worked with an artist and (it’s usually in logic in these scenarios) they say let’s turn that word up and they clip gain it up 3db and it doesn’t get louder but the compression and tone change. author: JustinLeu
content:
Like others have mentioned this is 100% going to start with tuning and performance. 

I can tell you how to get close to that sound…
-Bottom head tight.
-Top head tune medium and then depending on the number of lugs  completely loosen the 1 or 2 closest to you (normally just one)
-tighten the lugs next to the loose lug up to get the tone you want
-tighten the snares until the responded how you want 
-possibly add gaff or moon gel but de-tuning the lug will make it dead

Paul Maybury has a video on tuning like this I think. It’s a classic snare tuning “trick” and is super quick. You can take a drum from “medium” “classic” to  “dead/fat/indi” very quickly this way!

Above anything else…the drum needs to sound how you want it to before you mess with mics/compression👍

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Cian’s note on pokey frequencies is great. I mix banjo a lot (country music,) and I’ve got a couple thoughts that might be helpful if you’re not already finished. 
1) choose the top carefully. Where the “brightness” of the track is changes so much of how it’s perceived in the track. Chances are the top end is actually much lower than you’d expect. 
2) try compressing the shit out of it. Squash it allll to hell, kill the dynamics, RUIN the performance. There’s a good chance if it’s performed well it’ll turn into a punchy percussive element that adds size and excitement. 
3) make sure it’s balanced with another instrument on the other side of the the stereo field. If you don’t have one that’s playing something similar or has a similar top end, give it the old mono-verb/delay and see if that helps balance and keep it from being too distracting.
Hope that helps!

author: cian riordan
content: Well from experience, there are certain instruments that take better to additive high-mid saturation -- bass guitars, vocals, etc. Some others -- like certain brass instruments, violins, etc -- can get really harsh if you push those too far. I would start by going heavy handed on the most innocuous of the pile-up and see where that takes you. Saturation is a great way of doing this without making things pokey... but might be good to audition with an EQ first to see what zones you should focus in on. Once you have an idea of where you're going, then you can fire up Saturn 2 or Spectre or Neutron and go to work.

author: cian riordan
content: Just stops the compressor from overreacting on the low end material. Very rarely is it better to *not* have some HPF before the comp, even if you’re just snagging subsonic stuff.

author: ALXCPH
content: An important thing to remember about MB compressors is that you aren’t explicitly taking things out but rather re shaping the envelope of those frequencies. Which is what makes it a bit dangerous on the two buss as you won’t just be affecting the envelope of one sound. Not to be a purist at all but try and figure out what it is that it’s actually doing and how you can achieve something similar at the source. What you are describing sounds like your bass might be too loud. Or too long an envelope. There are other ways with much more control in which you can fix that issue. IMO.

Here are a few things I like to do with vocal FX:
- Chorus / Doubler that I then distort and will boost some high mid frequency (spectre is great for that)
- mono slap back is underrated, can be very appropriate in modern mixes
- Mentioned many times but compressing / distorting / EQing reverb returns (side chaining the compressor in the return with the dry vocal as key can really make vocal reverb bloom)
- Also, I don’t always tempo sync my delays, sometimes 300ms just works

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

Fun little adjustment to my mix world currently, based a little on @oaklandmatt’s reminder about boosting snare frequencies into a compressor for a certain pump. 

I tend to like to boost 1.5k on my bass tracks for grind & presence, but I moved that boost before the compressor and the way it reacted was reallllly pleasant. Evened out the overall dynamic control and moved the sound from slight tub & grind to even and gritty.

author: chrissorem
content: This is interesting, I do agree there are  often times decisions aren’t being made. I find that this is a side effect of everyone having the ability to be able to record from their home or wherever. It’s becoming more rare to have a record made with the traditional producer/engineer team working on a record From beginning to end. It’s more common a band will come in and track basics take it home for a few weeks try a bunch stuff out in their untreated room where they really can’t tell if they are adding something to the arrangement that’s muddying up a the song or if it  needs a different mic, positioning or eq ect. Or if in fact  it’s an orchestration issue.  Regardless they add it and send it to a mixer and say it sounds shitty because it hasn’t been mixed yet.  This is where I disagree with the whole “they’ve been living with it for however long so just make everything better than what they had”. Serban says somewhere down the line decisions haven’t been made. So even though I might get push back I’m going to try to do whatever  it is I think will make the mix better even if it’s crossing over into  the role of production. I can always give them back what they had but often the mix needs some things muted and calls for some big moves when the scenario above happens. I know some productions are not this case and require light lifting but in my world that hasn’t been the case.

author: James Cronier
content:
I’m wondering if anyone else has had this experience but for me, I was trying to lean on the mix bus to sort out things better resolved in the mix. 

I also found that by simplifying the mix bus, the choices I make on individual tracks come through clearer. A subtle 0.3dB move on a fader is much more audible to me when it’s not going through an 2 EQs, 2 compressors, a saturation thing, some kinda imager, and a limiter.

Instead all my hard work is done at the tracks themselves, and pulled forward slightly at the bus.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'd have a talk with the artist - if you haven't already - and get a feel for whether they want to keep it naturalistic (don't touch my performance!) or if they want to juice the sounds and have fun with the sonics - reverb moves, compression effects, weird balance proportions, fader rides, etc.

Without hearing the record, the risk with a lot of noise music is that it gets same-y. So dynamics and sonic interest are your friend. If you can find ways to create contrast and change over 30 second intervals that will go a long way towards engaging the listener. Then again, let's assume that the artist knows what they're doing and has it the way that they want.

If possible, I think it would be fun to invite them in to the mix session and collaborate on the mix with them sitting next to you. Go wild and see what inspires them! Make it into a performance and vibe off of the noise. That might be unorthodox when it comes to mixing records these days, but there's nothing orthodox about this stuff, so have fun!

author: chrissorem
content: @Slow Hand I almost always eq all fx and almost always make a a new verb or delay for  every new instance.  I can’t really think of a reason why I’d share fx unless I want something to melt together.  The fx end  up routing to their prospective group, for example vocal verb would go to vocal group ect and can be processed together if needed. I would almost never insert a verb on an individual track unless I want to push track back more into the mix. Or if I want a verb throw that simultaneously  turns the track down as I turn the verb up.  This is also the primary reason I don’t like inserting fx on a individual track. If you turn the fx up you are also Turing the dry down and in most cases I’m not trying do that. Also tend to process my fx, sometimes compression or saturation and also sometimes send fx to other fx. Example a delay feeding a verb

author: cian riordan
content: I like using Tupe for this. Boost that area on the EQ section then drive the “tubes” a little bit. A nice not subtle, but not overcooked way of doing it. Plus you don’t get all the compression artifacts if your vocal is already sufficiently contained dynamically.

author: JustinLeu
content: One thing to note with the “mix” amount, it really is a “maximum depth” control. Depending on what you are trying to accomplish you can drive the input/threshold (the actual knob labeled Depth haha)  but use the mix % to only reduce a small amount. Or (I find this to be how I use it on instruments most often) leave the “mix” 100% but play with the release until I’m only having to do a small amount of reduction but it sounds completely natural. This way if there is a crazy resonant spike I want to tame it will do it, but I am not having to hit the other areas hard at all.

author: chrissorem
content: For me the hardest part of mixing is scheduling.  The beauty in a tracking session is, that you are done at the end of the day.  When I send  mixes out I have zero control over when they will listen and give notes and when the project will be finished.  I tend to match the artist urgency or what works for my schedule. If they respond immediately I try and match that, if they wait two weeks it shows that it’s not that urgent unless discussed otherwise.  And at that point I add it to my list and prioritize accordingly.  If they ask when I will I work on it, I give an estimation “going to start  on so on so date…..   I’ve driven to the studio to many late nights to bust  “urgent” notes out to find I don’t hear from them for another week.  If it’s a big project, they will most likely have a team involved with real deadlines and I’ll make sure to meet those and generally management will put pressure on the artist to listen and give notes.  With Serban and Manny type operations, they don’t deal with any of this. They have a team to deal with it and they continue to mix accordingly.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ive got thoughts on this. First off, it’s the most confusing mixing adage ever, and I hate it. 
1) Everything doesn’t mean every individual thing. Multiple elements can live in a general area, combining to create a sound larger than the sum of its parts. In classical or film music they call that Orchestration.
2) Filtering is key. Recognize who lives on the bottom and the top and who’s in the middle somewhere, then clean out the muck. 
3) As Manny says: “mix with your heart.”
If mix advice sounds real simple to say but real hard to implement: IGNORE THAT SHIT.

*caveat* I’ve mixed & produced & played on major label shit, but I only started really mixing in 2020, so wtf do I know ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ We can learn from everyone but there’s only so much time in the day.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not sure if this is more #📺episode-talk, but there was chat in a recent pod about finding a good Audiomovers / remote mix notes session workflow. I've been having pretty smooth results since 2020 like this:


- Get clients on headphones (unfortunately a necessity for feedback/delay reasons, but I'm finding a lot of times that's how they listen to most music anyway, so they're very familiar with their headphones of choice). 

- Have them open your Audiomovers link.

 - Start a Facetime/Zoom call on your phone with whoever needs to be there. Mute your own Facetime mic on your phone, but clients leave theirs open. They'll hear your chat via the talkback mic you've set up in Tools.

 - Use talkback mic routing as pictured. If you're a Pro Tools nerd, you can probably work out what's going on by following the routing and sidechain assignments in the screenshot, but:


I print mixes and the limited ref (usually just tickling Pro-L 2) at the same time, so I make a Pre-Fade send to the Audiomovers bus from my Mix Print channel. This is also where the limiter lives, so their Audiomovers feed goes out at a healthy level.

My talkback channel (usually a 57) has a ducking compressor on it, sidechained from the Listen Print send and set to stun. This means my TB mic gets (more or less) muted during playback, so I can work on speakers while I make their tweaks. Muteomatic is still in my template, but I think I opted for the sidechained compressor because delay tails etc were getting double piped down to clients through my mic the moment playback stopped, whereas the compressor has adjustable release so it can come back up more or less as the tails die.

If any of that doesn't make sense, just lemme know and I can amend this post.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think it's important to recognize which "game" you're trying to play. Some people are playing the status game. Some people play the money game. Some people play the hit-making game. Some people play the artist/creativity/exploration game. Some people are playing the "I want to live in the woods and be left alone" game.

A big factor in stepping outside of these hierarchies is in your mindset. If you can be clear about what your actual values are then you will have a far easier time finding happiness and being satisfied leaving the other pursuits unrealized.

Then you can move laterally and pursue goals that are unique to you and that's probably the best thing that a lot of us have to offer the world: our opinionated, passion-driven, deep-diving life's work.

I mean hell, Spinoza was cast out from his Jewish community for his heretical and unconventional ideas about the nature of God. Now his *Ethics* is a beloved and wholly unique philosophical proof that endures and (to my knowledge) doesn't quite compare to anything else that people are doing in the field, even after several hundred years. He set himself apart by doing exactly what he wanted to. Shame he had to be exiled, though. 😭

author: JustinLeu
content: A few things I've found helpful is setting up my mix sessions with many points of control--- VCAs for all groups and then more specific (*All Music* *All Drums* *Kick/Snare* *All Vox* etc...) then a master fader controlling how hard I hit the 2bus. Starting with the biggest section of the song helps as well. I can then automate the other sections up or down *including the master fader feeding the 2bus*  As far as clipping/limiting on sources/busses I find it good to shape the sounds how I want (more heavy lifting) then the busses/2bus end up just glueing it together with a lighter touch. I think the 2bus doing too much of the lifting is where it can start to fall apart.

author: Deleted User
content:
Depending on the tools at your disposal and the exact situation I have a few suggestions:

Look for some low end in the performers vocals. Boosting with SPECTRE is nice but any eq can help add weight to a vocal if you’re boosting correctly. I would suggest having the dynamics tamed to your liking before boosting low end in a vocal because it can easily get out of hand

You could try duplicating the take, use RX de-reverb or whatever you can to remove as much ambience as possible, compress it heavily and blend it in. Obviously compression will bring out ambience so as to not let that become an issue try removing it beforehand. 

AVOX duo is a neat trick I use sometimes to help give a vocal some dimension. I use it on a send.

author: sukhuno
content:
Yeah dude - it has essentially all of the features of ValhallaDelay already built in... so how i do it is I find the right time pocket (1/4, 1/8, etc) and then set it up in a rack. Then i will mess w the EQ settings of the delay signal to give it the right freq content. I personally only use the ping pong and stereo modes (never really use the M/S). 

Then in the third tab i set up the ducking  and mess with the threshold and release settings to duck out of the way of the lead. I love the sound of the echo swelling up after the phrase is done so i'll usually start at -15 for theshold and ~100ms for release and experiment from there. that third tab also has noise, gate, and a wobble option to add some more character. Then just like the diffusion setting in valhalladelay - you can use the reverb and decay settings to add verb to the delay signal pre/on feedback/post in the chain to give it more softness/space. 

But the killer feature is then you can modulate these settings in the 2nd tab... then i add a little percentage change to one side of the ping pong delay ~1.3% so it's not completely locked in and just adjust settings from there. on the first page, you can also drive the input super hard to get a distorted sound and bring down the output level (like a preamp). It's super versatile and you can get big swelling verb echoes or overdrive space echo type sounds.

author: Rob Domos
content: This is also the biggest reason that analog synths have so much more solid of a lowend than any digital synth. It’s not the saturation giving you that solidity. It’s that hardware LPFs don’t have anywhere near the same amount of cascading delay differential. I.e. a software bass synth by default has a slight reverb that is phase canceling itself wellllllll into the passband (like all the way down iirc) just by the nature of it having a digital LPF bottlenecked at 44.1, where a moog filter has very little of that going on because the sample rate of the real world is infinite, or the speed of light, depending on how you look at it.

author: Dusk
content:
1) Goodhertz is known for its UI. I find Faraday to be intuitive in a way other limiters aren't for me. The ability to alter the saturation is great. The warmth slider that makes a sound feel warmer or cooler is super fun to me. It's not transparent, but the limiting is gentler, so I like it guiding a sound into its place. Its goal is to make the overall artifacts of limiting more pleasing
2) I find it faster, more versatile, and better for limiting than a Vari-Mu emulation. Not to mention the UI is way more helpful than what I'm used to with a plugin looking to remind us of a Fairchild or similar
3) Yes, it just doesn't brickwall, and it has a vibe
4) You don't Need Tupe if you have a saturator you already like, but I adore it. I was skeptical at first, but I demoed it on drums, and it changed my life. Always on drums and bass guitar for me. Again, Goodhertz's UI makes it more versatile than any other Tube and/or Tape emulator I've seen. It has a million options to tailor the saturation. The Opto Compressor and simple EQ are fast and versatile. It sounds good

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: On the subject of over-flattening vocals, I think we're definitely dealing with a cultural feedback loop of sorts here, not dissimilar perhaps to what's happened over the past few decades with autotune. More and more people are accustomed to vocals feeling this way, and not just dynamic flattening with overcompression, but emotional flattening as well. People are referencing vocals that feel like this. And by the time things get to us, they're often sufficiently dehumanized to the point where trying to inject more "natural" dynamics etc is already a fools errand

author: Rob Domos
content:
There are a lot of things that you’d usually want to fix regardless of any considerations in the track. Ie. Crazy plosives, mouth smacks, jacket rustling, mic stand bumping, noise fades, etc. I’ll typically get these janitorial fixes done without much thought of the context, (with the exception that I know to leave in a little more lip smack if it’s an aggressive rhythmic track than I do if it’s a ballad).  Beyond that my main thought is that I don’t want to hear the microphone. ie. mechanical sounding capsule buzz is something I tend to attenuate. 

All of this happens without me being able to hear the instrumental context (though I wish I could. RX integration into a daw context would be a game changer for me). 

Ruairi will rebalance the harmonics in a vowel, and while I also do that some in a vocal prep context, it’s harder because the undulation of resonances in a full musical context sometimes feels exciting while in solo it sounds off-putting. Ruairi gets to have the whole song in his RX window where I’m often only hearing the vocal, so I have to be a little more careful to imagine context and hedge my bets Hippocratic oath style, lest it looses some life.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
To expand on this...I think he thinks that most of the sounds he's receiving are about 90% finished. So his little EQ notches + 1-2dB of compression get to the finish line. And I think part of the reason it works for him is that he's probably right, obviously he's at a level where the productions are professional, and again obviously his mixes bump hard.

But I also think there are situations out in the world where sounds are 100% finished and those moves would be a step back. And obviously many situations where sounds are nowhere near 90% finished and need a heavier lift from the mixer. So if your producer clients are at a different place, then you'll need to be at a correspondingly different place to still add up to 100%.

He’s of course smart enough and skilled enough to perceive what’s what.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Sounds like you, me, and @herbie / other Nash folks should get together and make some tunes. I've been through many cycles like this similar to others here. I have a few thoughts:

I am skeptical of the sense of security that comes from what you call the 'overly busy' feeling. If 'constantly busy with work' = safe, then the moment work dries up you're under threat. That's a tough way to be and can undermine well-being in the long run.

The sense of security I derived from 'feeling busy' in the past was largely financial based. New projects meant a longer runway of cash-flow. I think we all have our own threshold with the fear, uncertainty, and doubt that stems from financial instability. Looming financial ruin can be motivating. Personally it makes me motivated and dumber. Past motivated dumb me hasn't always made good decisions for future me.

However one such decision that turned out to be good was starting about 7 years ago when my client work would slow I started making instrumental music and releasing it under anonymous artist projects. Client work would eventually come in then slow again and I'd make more inst music. Fast forward to now and it pays for all of my living expenses, I can invest more in my studio and the projects I truly care about. The downside is that time spent holing up alone making music is time that otherwise could have been spent building relationships and connecting with other people / artists / writers / producers. Oftentimes we are just a conversation away from the next great project.
