author: Brian Reynolds
content: I made it up. Take a synth for example. Set up a parallel send bus. Put the panner on the send. I usually compress it to smithereens. Blend it in underneath the main signal. You can get a lot of cool subtle movement. That can fill in the audio spectrum nicely. As example above could use subtle movement to fill out a pad. Or there are more adventurous circular 3D panning options that I find work well top end arps or vox chops. It was an idea born out of how people use 1/8 ping pong delays to fill out behind Bass guitar. Basically a different way to have the audio swim around subtly behind the main source. Try it. It's fun

author: matthewrederburg
content:
@diamndsdancin 

This is good advice. Early on I spent a lot of time using exclusively plugins that modelled "magic" analog pieces. These plugins were supposed to add "vibe" and "mojo" and "that sound." 

Some of these plugins are indeed great, but the hyperbole use to describe them distracted me from learning about compression as a tool to solve a problem. These standard controls, like attack/release times, are the key to making the tool effective. 

Once you understand the mechanical stuff a bit, the esoteric "vibe machine" plugins become even more fun. Like, you're telling me your new favorite compressor looks like a soviet radio and only has one knob labelled "BLAST?" Well now your trained ear can hear that the BLAST knob shortens the attack time as you turn it and that's why it pulverizes the leading edge of your sounds. You knew you liked the sound of it before, and that gut feeling is valuable, but now you know you can use this fictional soviet radio compressor plugin anytime you identify a problem that can solved by fast attack compression. Brain meet gut.

You also know that if you're in a situation without your new favorite fictional soviet radio compressor plugin, you can likely achieve similar results using a different compressor. All is not lost and you live to work another day.

author: cian riordan
content: This is why not leaning on the master bus compression too much is a good idea. Try subgrouping your instruments (drums, bass, guitars, synths, etc) and doing heavier compression on those sub-groups. That way if you turn up a synth it will only impact the compression scheme on that bus and not jam down the mix bus.

author: bobby k
content:
Ryan called me yesterday to geek out about a MELD workflow for buss compression. It essentially allows you to compile what’s contributing to the sidechain, and trim up/down certain elements post compression without affecting how the compressor is behaving. I used this for a drum buss yesterday and it was super neat. 

For me if im wanting a slammed buss sound I’m typically gaining down all drum mics that aren’t shells as I lean into the compressor. This let me instead trim up the shells post compression to the same effect. I then messed with just the oheads & crotch feeding the detector to see if the kick and snare was making stuff too pumpy.

I’m still wrapping my mind around this technique and I’d be curious to hear some of you guys weigh in on how you’ve found sidechaining effective in a live drum buss format!

author: oaklandmatt
Maxim
content:
I think that might be a limiting factor on top of the artists' abilities (Pop Smoke already sounded dope before his setup got professional https://youtu.be/317TP4JOSSE). I've recorded not-so-great rappers through nice chains and mixing wasn't the answer to save a (lacking) source. It never gave you *that* feeling. But even if you are recording great rappers cheaper mics tend to lack body and rarely have "boostable" or pleasant top end as you said. So it's a bit complicated before you even get to "mixing". Felt that was important to mention so you're not too hard on yourself.

But assuming that the limiting factor really is just mixing there's a bunch of options. First things first: is your monitoring and listening environment decent? Or are you on headphones? This could make placing vocals even harder for you. 

Then do you have a process that starts with vocal cleanup to get rid of or reduce unappealing harshness or performance issues? Despite being simple, people tend to skip basic tools like clip-gain to even out a performance. This should usually also give you some leeway for strategic boosts. Maybe instead of EQ look at harmonics. Fresh Air by Slate is free. Gem Dopamine is nice. Spectre is great. All of these should give you that "sizzle" you might be missing.

Then to get the presence and even out the performance you could try some parallel compression with something like an 1176. Also, try out Multiband Compression with the Mcdsp 404 or C6 or whatever you have to control the performance throughout the song once you've got a vocal sound you like.

I also find mixing the 808 & drums together with the vocal the most useful when it comes to gain staging and getting the song to feel right.

Obviously, there's more that could be said but I find processes more helpful than tools. It's art at the end of the day. Attached what Serban's assistant sees as their/his "mixing process". Mix more and experiment with what you have. Get feedback from the artists.

author: mixedbywong_my

author: Adam Thein
content:
If retracking is still an option maybe that's the ideal solution, but three things that come to mind to me to try if it's pretty extreme is pulling up the audio in RX and using the lasso tool to just track that sweep (it should be pretty visible and consistent if it's bad enough you are automating an EQ to duck the resonance) and just gain that down enough to be able to use other tools more effectively).  Another thing I'd try if you have it is soothe2 if you can get it to mostly work on that resonance without killing the tone (even maybe these both in combination) and then finally I'd try something like Saturn or Kclip in multiband and try and use a combination of dynamics and saturation within that band to tame it further.  If it's really bad maybe a combination of those 3, or just automating an EQ but that sounds grueling and time consuming if it's throughout the entire performance.  Maybe Surfer EQ could also accomplish this but I don't have that plug.  I also think there's a Surfer EQ type function in Nectar or Neutron?  Somebody that knows Izotope's stuff better than me can probably chime in.

My 2 cents and probably there are some better solutions out there but this is where I'd start personally!

author: mixedbywong_my
content:
Id assume it be a slightly slow attack in a context of a limiter instead of a compressor (longer attack time) 
You can if the limiter has a look ahead function built in. Taken from the fabfilter Pro L manual 
“Lookahead
The Lookahead knob sets the look-ahead time for the initial 'transient' stage. This allows the limiter to examine the incoming audio in advance and predict the amount of gain reduction needed to meet the requested output level. If the look-ahead time is very short, the limiter doesn't have much time to move to the desired level: this will generally have the effect of preserving transients better and increasing the apparent loudness, but at the expense of possible distortion. Longer look-ahead times are safer, but less loud, and transients might appear to get lost in the mix a little more.”

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Multiband Comps are legit voodoo. I’ve been working with ProMB for a year and only now starting to feel ok about it. Couple things:
1) sometimes your mixed is well balanced, but overall lacks or has too much of a certain area, so a multiband can help address intermittent problems  without destroying the whole area of a mix like eq might. 
2) dynamic eq > multiband UNTIL you want to address attack & release times 
3) crossover / phase issues scare me, and trying to understands them technically before just using the ProMB just gave me analysis paralysis. 
4) try some of the basic presets on your plug, gain match, and then do the blind toggle test. Easy and takes no time at all.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well I'd say they were *designed* to do the same thing, but when it comes to actually coding the low-level DSP there are going be differences in how it's programmed/built.

Think of it like trying to null the Waves 1176 plugin and the Bomb Factory 1176 that comes with Pro Tools. They're aiming for the same target (emulate an analog 1176), but they were both built by different teams, and thus there will be variations that keep them from nulling, even if they're designed to do the same thing.

That said, I don't hear any appreciable difference between the two OTTs. For me it comes down to the Xfer Records plugin having  a more intuitive set of controls, so it's got my vote. 🙂

author: Zack Hames
content:
I almost never use multiband comp tbh. I use multiband saturation all the time with Saturn.

The general reason i use it is to brighten something without simply adding a high shelf, or to create a broader wider transient on a drum track. The distortion with splay out the sharp transient. So I’ll saturate high end on vocals or bass to get more openness without harsh high end boosts, I’ll use the same sort of settings on close mics on acoustic drums to get more attack and punch. 

This is an Oversimplification but Nothing is bad in excess if it sounds good.  There are no rules.

author: Deleted User
content:
1. Corrective EQ in the Upper midrange/high end, notching out all the harsh resonances, taming the pick transients if the bass is played with a pick. I love the way MAAT Santa Cruz does this ever so smoothly. 
2. I compress the bass with a compressor sidechained to a LPF(!), to get some low end body which is usually severely lacking. The LPF is set between 1000-2000 hz, attack 0-8 ms and release 200-400 ms depending on the tempo of the song/bass part. Reducing 3-5 dB on peaks. This gets me really far.
3. If the bass is a shortscale, I’ll use Goodhertz Tiltshift to move the low mids from around 200 hz to around 100 hz, out of the way of the guitars. 
4. Then I put an amp emulation on the channel. Whichever one floats your boat. Plugin Alliance B15, Guitar Rig, TSE BOD, whatever. I’ll be boosting low end and cutting high end here, or before with a separate instance of Tiltshift. 
5. If I want the bass to sound „rock“ and cut, I send it to a parallel distortion, which can be anything. I like TSE BOD, which is another sansamp copy which  has a lot of sub. My trick here is to add a clipper before the sansamp to really get extra gnarl. Logic‘s stock Bitcrusher works great, but I’m sure anything works.

author: Deleted User
content:
It’s also worth listening if it’s attack portion or the sustain that is getting buried. 

If there is not enough attack on the bass, you can sometimes trigger sample (percussive sample, sometimes a really short foley thing) that has the right presence area to have a little something that adds a punch to the bass. I often just copy one note that works into other parts that don’t cut through but this stuff only works sometimes. It doesn’t really work with busier bass parts

And sustain wise, compression can help when it’s done right or make it worse when it isn’t done right. Same with saturation. I think with sustain, there’s a lot of nuance in how you want the sustain to sit- performance is a huge part of this. Sometimes there’s too much bright stuff and it doesn’t allow the sustain to be audible, if you can tell something’s down there but you can’t really feel it or hear it that might be the issue. I noticed when there’s too much or wrong compression on other upper elements, it becomes an issue. 

Also dup the track and start new and see where you can take it, sometimes there’s too much going on and hard to track what’s causing what.

author: ALXCPH
content:
20% is a metric ton of saturation imo. 

Soft Clip Classic

This is the default algorithm, and it’s the same one, which was used in the previous version.

Soft Clip Pro

This new algorithm has a slightly different characteristic. It compresses an adjustable dynamic range by half. A line in the function plot shows from which level the saturation begins. The dynamic integrity below this threshold stays intact.

25% - compresses the last 6 dB into 3 dB, and adds 3 dB
50% - compresses the last 12 dB into 6 dB, and adds 6 dB
75% - compresses the last 18 dB into 9 dB, and adds 9 dB
100% - compresses the last 24 dB into 12 dB, and adds 12 dB

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’m only dealing with digital clicks very rarely. Usually on loop edges, so you can deal with them and make a new loop (you might have to copy-paste a kick transient or guitar attack from elsewhere).

Vast majority of cases are mouth noises, often on in-breaths or ends of words (but everywhere in between too - squelchy mouth closes and opens, all sorts really).

Totally depends on the singer. Some are fiends for it, some less so. Especially if they need a drink - a sip of water can save work down the line.

They’ll usually be more apparent in quieter phrases, closer to the mic etc. where the “signal to noise” (ie vocal to clicks) ratio is lower.

I work largely in pop, so layers of compression and generally a brighter vocal balance exaggerate them, plus the lead vocal tends to be forward in mixes, in arrangements that lend themselves to vocal clarity in the upper mids and above.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If I'm totally rebalancing drums, I'll treat them as if I'm tracking them myself and building a basic working drum sound.This *usually* goes as follows, and I like to do it *very* quickly (as if the drummer is in the live room playing and everyone's waiting):

1. Mute everything.
2. Pull up kick in and out (+ sub or whatever they've recorded). Play with balance and phase of kick out until it feels good (good is context dependent - sometimes that's deep/subby/slow, sometimes that's punchy/percussive etc).
4. Bring up overheads along with kick mics. Flip overhead phase and play with balance til it sounds cool, or punchy, or whatever you're after. Sometimes there's a very obvious right or wrong answer, but often just figure out whatever works for the drum groove + arrangement + song. Where the bass sits can often help tell you what config will work best.
5. Solo snare mics, get them in phase with each other (just listen together and flip usually snare bottom until the blend sounds cool to you - often I'm looking for whichever configuration has more "thud", but that's context dependent). 
6.Unsolo and check snares against kicks and overheads. If you need to flip the snares, flip both top and bottom (or whatever combo) together so their relative phase remains intact. 
6. Add in rooms, again flipping and balancing til shit feels cool. Do same for crush mics, any other flavour stuff.

Toms are usually my last concern. Unless the groove is tom heavy, they might do only 2 or 3 hits across the whole song, so as Ryan said - hand gate those fuckers and deal with them once the general sound is dialled in.

The one thing I really do believe in is compressing on the way in. Singers will sing totally differently in response to the squish. 

<deep breath>

author: Ross Fortune
content:
+1 on Trigger Gate from Ryan’s recommend.

The Oxford drum gate is also pretty unique in how you can have frequency dependent release - ie the fundamental of the snare can ring on longer, but the crack happens then disappears before the hihat wash becomes over exaggerated 

BX SSL 4k gate can be very precise (and in Fast mode you can use the “snap” as it opens as part of the sound), but I’m in the habit of creating separate gate trigger versions of the kick and snare - super heavily gated (and filtered + compressed) versions of the kick in and snare top. 

I commit the processing on those, mute them but then have them pre fade sending to SC Kick and SC Snare buses. Super handy for lots of functions - either very precise and malleable gate open and close on the audible drums themselves, but also for instrument sidechains, maybe Pro-MB ext input on a bass track, a sine generator under the kick / noise generator on snare, the Slate Trigger feeds etc. 

Having the gate triggers as audio allows you to slide them a couple samples back and forth as needed for groove or faux lookahead. 

Maybe there’s easier ways to do things (it’s a somewhat old school technique), but making them is one of my prep steps and they do get used in every session.

author: Zack Hames
content:
What makes them think they *should*?  Steve Albini's Eletrical Audio videos are genuinely amazing and worthwhile technical guides to these types of things. If he's doing it maybe the person who's been mixing for two years should think twice about posting a video about compression ratios. It's not necessary.

And, there is a difference between someone out of the interest in their own heart and wanting to help, posting a "hey, some people ask this question and I think I have a helpful answer, here it is". Rather than "WELCOME TO "PRO AUDIO DUDE ACADEMY, TODAY WE ARE GONNA TALK ABOUT COMPRESSION" and then it's sponsored by some plugin company and they are telling you to smash that subscribe button.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So when I’m thinking about glue, I’m mostly thinking about frequency cohesion. Like where is the top of the vocal? How do I get the top of the snare to live there too? Are my perc tracks or BGVs adding density to the sides? Or just motion? Do my bass and kik muddle each other or enhance? It’s almost always an eq question for me…
Of course I never stopped using compression so we may be on different paths. And of course Cian is 100% right. Now that you’ve learned the “why,” it should be very easy to hear what the comps are doing and how to use them to benefit your tracks.

author: Joshua Riley
content:
I’ve been using HitSend and honestly so many more pros need to hear about it! It’s got file management, mix notes, mix versions, invoicing and payment all built into one platform. I setup a project with the name and everything, setup the invoice and can choice whether I want a deposit or not, then create a playlist and add the mixes to that, Artist can add notes etc, you can go through multiple versions and then once it’s done, you add the files to the deliverables folder, they can click approve which will take them to a payment gateway to settle the invoice and straight after that, they download the deliverables package
There’s a few deeper tools as well such as password locking, who has access to what, if you’re just sharing a link you can choose which link has the ability to comment and approve, you can bring on project members as well so that they can manage the project and files and a few automation integrations as well as email notifications for everything. Also has google drive and Dropbox Integration

author: Nomograph Mastering

FFT based processors like DSM and Soothe are the most powerful but also often have the most potential to damage your source

author: LAPhill
content:
There's a distinction worth making between experimenting (at any stage of the process) and waffling. I've seen whole scores get changed at the 11th hour because, two days before wrapping, they discovered a better melody and then had to go change every cue that had it. There was quick decision-making in the "oh shit, we all agree this is actually better," but keeping the doors open to new ideas until the very last minute. 

My point is that inspiration can strike at any point. Hearing a great mix might reveal a more unique arrangement idea, or new harmonies, etc. etc... And I don't think there's anything wrong with that, we're all in service of the music. But there's an ocean of difference between that and "I played this for the receptionist at my sister-in-law's car dealership and she thought the kick drum was too loud, so I think we should revisit it"

author: Adam Thein
content: I like to reach for brighter verbs in this kind of scenario - something with some texture like a spring or a plate or a digital verb with some texture.  Start there, mess with the width of it first.  Generally think if it more as a synth pad layer.  Emphasizing 2-5k if it really needs to cut with spectre or Saturn or a brighter saturation.  Using a delay in combination so that the decay envelope has some movement so my ear latches onto it more.  Panning, modulation, tremolo, etc, subtle ways to grab attention even at low level.  And good old volume automation.  Printing the verb can help give you some visual feedback for how it’s decaying.

author: chrissorem
content: I do analog summing when I mix so  I have daw  groups that feed final daw  output groups that feed my console. Generally I try to not share fx between groups and designated fx that feed the groups. Example: vocal verb or delays outputs go to vocal group. This give an option to eq compress or saturate and melt together if intended. If I don’t want that I send the fx to their final outputs. Example: vocal verb output doesn’t go to vocal Group but to vocal output to console. This is a good workflow for making stems ect as well.

author: Ingmar Carlson
content:
1. I’ve never actually tried it as a final limiter to cap a mix, but I’m not sure it makes much sense to think about it as a “limiter” in that sense. More helpful to think of it as a compressor I think. 
2. Also don’t experience it as a “true” Fairchild emulation. I’ll reach for other plugs for that. I tend to think it’s better than a model, actually, and much more useful far more often. I love it for its transparency more than its ability to approximate any classic hardware, though it’s also incredible when you’re pushing it into more colorful territory. Love the functionality too; much preferable to me than nudging knobs around with my cursor! 
3. See 1 👆 
4. If you haven’t demoed Tupe yet, I’d say do that first and see if it does something for you than, say, Decapitator or Saturn. For me it’s a completely different animal, and better than the above!

author: Zach Hughes
content: Faraday is the most musical sounding limiter plugin I've found. Just as useful on individual elements as it is for bus work. The ratio defaults to 20:1 but you can change to 8:1 or 4:1. Also has some tasty tone control. I use it on almost every mix along with Tupe. Tupe is awesome for adding subtle saturation, density, color, etc... If you like tubes you'll like tupe. Also get a nice opto comp built in and nifty emphasis control. I've found both to be great tools for production / mix work.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: @itaylerner i’ve had good results with Supertone Clear (used to be known as Goyo) plugin to deaden bleed on a vocal, and for more demanding cases RIPx (good because you can preview/tweak) and UVR - good separation but lacking in realtime interaction. My usual routine is printing different passes with different levels of reduction and then putting these processed takes in playlists synced to the original, this then allows me to comp between ‘reduction’ takes. I find it’s good to do this work separately to the actual mixing, or at least have a break before you mix as it can lead you down some dark alleys of bleed reduction. The passive listening Ruairi mentioned yesterday is key. It’s about controlling the bleed a bit better so that your vocal can be presented better.

author: Rollmottle
content:
"What if I don't grind 10 hours straight on this song, how could it possibly be good?" 
"If it doesn't sound like Jon, it won't be good" 
"What if I didn't nail the mix with minimal moves?"
"What will they think if I didn't compress?"
"What if I over-process, they'll think I'm a hack."
"What if I under-process, they'll think I'm a hack."

It sounds like you have to connect with FEELING the music rather than intellectualizing what it may or may not be or what it may or may not mean for you as a person. You gotta find a way to operate from confidence, not fear. Gotta get out of your head.

But lots of time I'll be using the mono mic to pick up the meat of the kit and then just use L & R as cymbal mics.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Hey great question!  Even with “include return and master effects” checked in the export settings in Live, your tracks won’t 1:1 with dynamics processing or non linear processing (saturation) without using external side-chain routing.

I’d have a discussion with your mixer about if they’d like you to remove your mix bus or if they’d like it baked into each track/stem you are printing.  If it’s the latter, you can create sidechain source tracks to feed plugins that allow for an external sidechain input to keep it closer to 1:1 (still likely not fully accurate with the nonlinearities in some analog modeled plugins).

This is a pretty tough thing to type out but if we can find a few minutes today where our time overlaps I’m down to hop on a VC and show my workaround for this situation in Ableton.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Going back to @h3x ‘s og question- I think the framing of this can only lead to misleading or unhelpful responses. 

Maybe a better question is: when should I reach for multiband compression on the 2buss? What problems can it help me solve? What creativity can it help inspire?

author: JakeTB
content:
Here’s the long-winded human version. We’re still on this learning journey so happy for any pushback or insight

For the most part, our group felt the tradeoffs of very subtle multiband often outweigh the benefits, since just putting those crossovers in the signal makes a bigger difference than, say, a dB of control.

We felt more liberal use of multiband can add an aggression and excitement that is very familiar and unique, and prefer treating it as a sweetener or energizer over the whole mix more than trying to control problem areas that could be addressed on tracks.

In the signal chain, its position can drastically effect how other tools behave. Up front, it can help a bus compressor or saturation device behave more predictably, but may mush things too much. Near the end, it allows those devices to play a more colorful role but may cause weird behavior when using fast, “transparent” limiters afterward. I like it first right now, most of our group like it near the end.

The hallmark signs of overuse for us were mixes that sound overly strident or when a vocal becomes inconsistent tonally from section to section as density changes.

Tools-wise, the group unanimously preferred minimum phase tools over linear phase or dynamic phase. OTT is a starting point, ear training to recognize that color. Once you hear it at 15-20%, you won’t be able to unhear it on many pop records. After ingraining that color, ML4000 and C4 both have their own flavors that can do a thing while offering tweakability when needed.

author: elvis
content:
So, I’m a long-time follower of this thread, but have been to scared to post any questions as I’m afraid to look like a total dumb ass…

I’m a singer/songwriter/guitarist who has been teaching myself how to record/mix over the past few years. I don’t totally suck, but I have a long way to go.

I’m working on a mix for a client—yes that’s new for me—and I want to kill myself 🙂

Basically, it’s a big, dumb rock song (I.e. Foo Fighters), and I can’t for the life of me reign in the drums—in other words, there’s freaking cymbal bleed in EVERY mic. So, I have this situation where I tame the shitty cymbals—then get something that sounds like kick and snare samples playing along to a vacuum cleaner. Mostly because I’ve put every stinking plug-in like Soothe, multi-band compression and dynamic EQ on the overheads and rooms. Yeah! My cymbals don’t poke your ears out—but, they also sound like a Rumba.

And gating did not work as the drummer is hitting his shitty cymbals on every freaking beat! I ended up sampling a god forgive—clean snare hit and using that as a sample. It’s okay, but without being able to raise the level of the rooms and overheads, I’m kind of fucked.

I found myself referencing this Joel Hamilton production/mix of a Highly Suspect song as it’s kind of similar to what I’m working on. It’s on Puremix. He’s pretty amazing. And while the music isn’t my thing—it sounds awesome. His mix sounds big and organic—while mine sounds like an electric ham sandwich.

Without hearing the song, I don’t know how much advice I can expect. I just mostly want to vent…

I sometimes wonder if I’m the one that sucks, or is it the source material? When do you know you’ve done the best you can with what you’ve been given? You can’t polish a turd. 

And as a newbie dipshit, I’m trying so hard to make whatever I do be super awesome, badass—whatever that means. But, maybe I just need to make the rough mix sound 20% better. I don’t know.

Wow! That was long. Thanks for any advice…

author: spookydrums
content: An IR is also a static image of a dynamic thing (which makes me think of the lyric «recorded music is a statue of a waterfall» from last year’s Mount Eerie record), so to me it actually feels less realistic in a way, a very reduced version of a highly complex thing. It definitely has it’s uses though! But like for instance if you think of sound being transmitted through a spring in a spring reverb, every impulse will hit the spring on a different part of the spring’s travel from side to side and will impact how the vibrations transmit through it in such a complex way, while every time an impulse hits the spring reverb IR it will be «transmitted»  from the same starting point

Let's say the performance is wildly dynamic and has big swings in volume, then you'd be looking to solve that with some form of compression and/or volume automation. Keep solving problems until they're arent any.

author: earwormfarmer
content: I’ve got nothing against using compression and Eq and that’s typically what I would do for something like this. But this specific case was really giving me a hard time. Lowest note on this upright track was hitting about 7db louder than the higher notes. Sounds like the mic was close up to the body/ f hole and not getting enough of the neck. After trying different EQ + compression techniques, automation just sounded a bit more pleasing to my ears. And made it easier to stick with the up and down dynamics of the song. Which is also very up and down. I could compress then ride a fader to match the track, but either way I’m automating. This song is more in the chamber music world and super dynamic, so EQ / compression moves I would do on other stuff felt more aggressive.

author: Deleted User
content:
Jeff Ellis made a great point in his course about the difference. He says, it’s about “poignancy”. A compressor doesn’t differentiate between a word or phrase that should stand out from the others. That’s why he uses clip gain to level out stuff beforehand. 

Ofcourse you can make the point of leveling out with a compressor and then automating up poignant words or phrases. But most modern vocal recordings have to be edited anyway so why not go in and do it all there?

author: cian riordan
content:
Agreed. I used to use one for years and was always excited at the impact and loudness I could get out of it — but I go back and listen to mixes from 10+ years ago and I was really overusing them and I don’t think the work stands the test of time. I was using a pretty rudimentary clipper EV had developed but still, even with the modern standards, I find similar results.

I’m definitely having success with them upstream though, particularly on drum bus. I think it’s a great, transparent way of lopping unnecessary transient material before bus compressor and  limiters start doing their thing. That way, I can use those tools more for tune shaping and texture and less for just getting the level up.

author: Brodie Stewart
content:
I mean, all tools are basically a form of:
- EQ
- dynamics
- saturation
- time based effects

Not to mention the importance of fader balance, phase, and panning!

But all the fancy tools end up just being some combination of the above. And maybe certain specialised tools solve problems a little faster, but it’s still using a combination of the above.

author: wcalebparker
content:
With regard to the “practicing new concepts” thing - for me it depends on the situation. The other day I was working on a live thing and I needed to deal with some bleed. My usual tools weren’t cutting it, so I spent a little time digging into another tool which I thought might do the job well. The deadline isn’t particularly tight so I had the leisure.

I think depending on where you are in your career, it can be really helpful to use someone else’s mixing philosophy as a learning tool, but if people are coming to you for what you do, client projects are probably not the time for that.  

In my head there’s a pretty big difference between exploring a new reverb plug to potentially generate some inspiration and deciding, “on this project I’m SIDE-CHAINING EVERYTHING” when that hasn’t been your thing in the past.

But also, I don’t really think about this that much, and I think you’ll probably have to develop your own feel for what’s appropriate for you. But I wouldn’t  recommend watching MWTM and changing your entire workflow mid project (although I’ve admittedly done this in the past 😂)

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
Voxengo Span and TDR Prism are amongst the best analyzers out there, you can actually set them in order to show information about dynamics across the spectrum, but It will not say anything about what you are really doing to the sound when dialing a compressor.
As @thegreatcarsoni said, graph-style gain reduction meters (like in Pro-C or Pro-L) are the most we can have visually, but still, other than the amount of dBs you are reducing, and maybe the average shape of the release, it will not be very helpful.

Ya well, using plugin doctor might help, you can see the transfer curves and look at the harmonics that are added and stuff like that.

I also found that using the delta function on TDR free kotelnikov compressor helped me listen to what’s happening more clearly - hearing what’s being impacted by the compression rather than what remains after it’s done is a helpful perspective to gain.

author: chrissorem
content: I agree with  Justin, you want to be accommodating and the  goal is everyone including yourself  to be happy with the mix. that being said, not everyone is made equal some people really struggle with making decisions and moving forward and hyper obsess about small details. In my experience those notes are only for the artist and generally never makes for a better song or mix so I try to plow through those notes. There’s no real answer to this question because everyone’s so different but I’m now pretty good at distinguishing people that let these things linger on and i kind of force them down a road for example OK please send me a consolidated one sheet of all your notes or let’s knock this out in one last in person session of course those don’t generally end there but what I will do afterwards just put value to my time and tell them we need to work hourly and that I have other projects that are gonna start demanding my time this helps them make decisions. for me, it’s never about the number of revisions, but more about what the revisions are.  I try and steer people out of the weeds with notes like can we try  this compressor to see what it sounds like? In short if you don’t value your time, don’t expect others to.

author: onanisland
content:
yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: ALXCPH
content:
This is over simplified but.
If you want “loud 808s” it’s all about levelling everything around it. Clipping your drums for a “loud” impact but low peak level.
Thin out your instruments/loops to make it seem like the bass is bigger than it is when it comes in. Because a bunch of the low mids will come from the 808. 
Saturation and clipping is your friend here.

author: David Fuller

author: Eric Martin

author: cian riordan
content: This is empirically false. The mix knob is the last gain stage and decides the blend of compressed signal vs. uncompressed signal to output. The compressor -- including the ratio of gain reduction -- operates independent of this.

author: cian riordan

content:
TikTok sonics question for anyone who might know: working with an artist who’s posting stuff there often, and a song we just got done, they’re having trouble with what (to me) sounds like TikTok adding some wild limiter. 

Scenario I think is going on is that it’s a super quiet part of the song going into a huge downbeat, so my guess is that there’s some auto gain compression happening on TikTok’s end to gain up the quiet part, but it’s not “catching up” in time when the downbeat happens, so it gets all limit-y/crush-y smashed for a moment. The track itself sounds good on a phone speaker, so it’s not a phone issue. It’s something to do with TikTok’s encoding after it’s been uploaded. 

Anyone have insight to the ways of TikTok?

author: h3x
content: The way the human ear perceives “more reverb” is through a longer pre-delay. The decay is the ringing out of said reverb. Turning it up is just the volume of said reverb. Pre-delay is super important to fit in the pocket so that u dont need to turn it up loud to feel/hear the reflections and separation

author: Rob Domos
content: A lot of self exploration tbh. That and over a dozen voice teachers, a half a dozen singing courses, etc. I picked up random pieces from all over and synthesized that accumulated knowledge together as a 15 year process. TBH never once have I encountered a single system that I think does an adequate job of giving someone a complete, useful, and accurate understanding of the mechanics of the voice. Have you ever seen one book that would tell you everything needed to be a good engineer? It’s the same thing. They all fall short pretty hard, and FWIW the people who study them the most very often don’t sound that good to me.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
For rock and folk music I generally just do subgroups like drums, bass, guitars, leads, bvs, lvs. For pop oriented songs generally more split out/ kick, snr, toms, hats, cymbals, fx, different synths split out etc. i just use soundflow scripts that solo and bounce what I tell it to and run it at night or at lunch. Freezing tracks first can make it go way faster. As for mixbuss, I take off my final limiter (or turn down the input, however the song was sent to mastering)… I’m usually not compressing the buss hard enough for it to matter. Sometimes the sum of the stems ends up sounding better than the mix! Generally people are using them for their MD to create a live show, or for dance remixes etc. For sync most people seem happy with instrumental and accapella in my experience so far?  Also if your trying to key your mix buss compressor from a printed mix, freezing most of the session first (besides fx etc and aux tracks) seems to help the side chain feel pretty close to what the mix was. I don’t bother with it though most of the time as I’m doing a couple db at most on the buss comp.

Edit: one other idea I’ve messed with pre soundflow, is, if your just doing subgroups and have the routing setup, save your mixbuss as a track preset and when your ready to print recall it on all your masters and commit the tracks. It works for me unless im using too much uad etc.

author: BillyC
content: Multiplicity is significantly deeper and more configurable than Soothe, which for me solves any given problem more efficiently and transparently. It's a plugin that renders any distinction between dynamic EQ and multiband compression mostly useless.  Here's a single band preset I made with the goal of targeting upper midrange harshness that only requires custom Threshold and Q settings. I'm not sure how useful it is because it really isn't that far from the default! Mainly using a butterworth instead of the standard BPF.

author: Zack Hames

I usually try to have some sort of stereo element to them if I can as well, so it isn't just two mono vocals stacked on each other (unless that is the vibe)

author: mixedbywong_my

Usually for me I try to get the volume automation right for the music level first , then on the music bus , there is a fabfilter Pro-MB doing slightly bit of ducking triggered by the voice over track/bus. Usually I’ll set the pro MB to be compressing the music track from say 200hz to 6-7khz ducking the mid channel . 
Sometime a fairly wide cut at 2khz is needed. (1-2db) 9/10 times just the pro-MB. As long it’s not really pumping when the ducking is happening hence the initial volume automation move .

author: Maxim
content: Guess this depends on your philosophy. Some mixers prefer compression to EQ and that’s where it can come in handy to control a sound. I believe Serban still uses the ML4000 on his mixbus. Would be surprised if it’s doing much though. JJ same story — he really goes in with Multiband on Vocals too. Other people might just use it to tame a specific frequency range instead of EQing it. But since dynamic eqs are a thing that’s gotten less popular I guess.

author: Maxim
content: I wouldn’t use more than 2 bands on vocals anyways to avoid unnecessary crossover points. One band to control everything under say 1k and one band to control above could already give you interesting results. I would also keep the settings pretty much identical and only use a low ratio (2.1 or below). The idea is to let the compression trigger based of how the vocal performance might change in the lower and higher registers throughout the song. Of course this is pretty useful with problematic performances. But maybe not something to slap on by default.

author: Maxim
content: Yeah it’s interesting. I really wasn’t into multiband on vocals before trying it. I prefer it with the high band (B4) disabled though. So maybe there is something other than compression going on.

author: Slow Hand
content: Have you tried disabling the compression or upward expansion on each of the three bands? It's not immediately obvious that you can do so by looking at the GUI, but if you Cmd+click on the left or right side of each band's meter (the green parts) they will disable and become *way* less noisy and unwieldy.

That's something I can agree with forsure. Clipping often gets disregarded and people will often reach for compression, saturation or even limiting before they reach for a clipper. It's indeed important to use it where needed tho, I see it as just another tool in my toolbox, but I will use saturation or compression when I feel like that's what the sound needs. Apart from that I think doing anything to dynamics is always better if done in stages. Different stages of compression, limiting and in this case clipping, so I definitely think that's a good approach

author: Slow Hand
content:
Got a question for my Audio DSP nerds: Does convolution of two audio signals introduce phase shift?

Convolution is most often used for reverbs, where phase shift is acceptable. But what if you convolved your audio signal with a fixed EQ curve that is 1 sample in duration?

As we all know, using a normal EQ imparts phase shift around those frequency bands, and an EQ curve with *lots* of bands, is likely to be a big, smeary, mess that distorts your phase relationships.

What if you took a big complicated EQ curve (like the type that you'd see on a Sonarworks correction curve), sampled that, and then used it with a convolver plugin to re-apply that same complex filter to your mix buss? Would this method sidestep the phase shift that you get from using traditional EQ bands?

author: Will Melones
content: You would need a reeeeeallllly long attack time on a compressor to imitate what a gate would do. And a gate will stay open as long as the signal is above the threshold. A compressor will clamp down (perhaps slowly, depending on attack time) and stay clamped down until the signal passes below the threshold. And then all of the ‘noise’ will be raised by makeup gain to the level of the peaks. Very opposite effect from a gate, but it could be used as a transient shaper in that way

author: Will Melones
content: If you’re thinking more of an expander, like a gradual gate (lol), that’s like a compressor with negative ratio. Increasing the distance in volume between the highest highs and the lowest lows.

author: Will Melones
content:
Mine is half a page and I’m convinced people don’t read it. I would find 4 pages overwhelming, and I keep up with all the messages in this discord 😅

I’m finding it better to pick my battles, and cut it down to the point where it’s helpful to the client (so they have less to ask about before delivering) and not just my list of demands. 

Last month I stayed in an Airbnb, and there were notes and instructions everywhere. Pages of checkin and checkout instructions on the website, a folder of rules on the table, and handwritten operational manuals taped to every appliance. Mostly it was just confusing, overwhelming, and a lot of requests that we failed to follow before we even knew what was being asked of us.

author: Ross Fortune
content: It has to be this for me. I find it impossible to guess how much each Ess will come up after rounds of EQ into compression into EQ in to compression, so I'll end up having to redo it anyway towards the end of the mix

author: Ross Fortune
content: My philosophy here (logically and sonically, for my mixing sanity) is Waves DeEsser before any compression. The compression will exaggerate the esses, so I'm trying preventative measures that'll hopefully lead to less curing downstream. Vocals usually go to hardware UA 6176 or Tubetech MEC 1A, which will be doing some compression. They'll be roughly set pretty much from the outset of the mix just so I have a semi working vocal to mix the early stages around.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If it's really upsetting me I might deal with it early, but I prefer to live with those details as I get the drum mix together - there's (usually) going to be bus compression, maybe added fake Oceanway room, samples and their idiosyncracies - so many variables, all often getting processed on drum bus (+ potential parallels per song section).

By the time I'm done with that it usually just feels more like a general vibe than an exercise in precision - the snare ring in the left room mic might draw the ear away from the kick flam in the right (or that flam could now groove in a cool way as the comps breathe, or it slaps against a rhythm guitar part or whatever), but I can always go back and Time Adjuster (or L/R EQ with Fab or whatever) the rooms if they're really bothering me.

Same reason I don't usually address snare rings until I've got the drums working well

author: cian riordan
content: For me its all about parallel drum busses. One clean, wide open -- that preserves all the transient information, which you can exaggerate further with transient tools. One very compressed -- distressor style, to bring up the life in the room. And one distorted -- usually something like Decapitator with a low-shelf before it. I feel like in this situation, you could have your cake and eat it with what you're looking for.

author: Deleted User
content: Here’s the signal diagram from the manual. I can tell you what I do. I’m mixing through it the entire time. I’m always in soft clip classic. I start with the soft clip saturator slider at 25% (this controls knee shape and saturation level which will add gain). The clip slider is your threshold for where you want the clipping to occur however with the soft saturator knob above 0% there’s a knee to it. The output is post clipping and ignore the ceiling since you’ll likely be using a limiter following this.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Come on dude, there's a reason this type of misleading promotional pricing is ruled illegal - at least in the UK.

I'm sure we're all savvy enough in here to understand that marketers earn their wage by exploiting weaknesses (widely documented and scientifically substantiated) in human psychology. The felt urgency created by countdown timers and sale price indicators ("normal" prices slashed out, bold colours advertising "temporary - don't miss this" pricing etc) causes consumers to make irrational decisions and hurriedly complete purchases they otherwise wouldn't have made. I guarantee everyone in here has felt those psychological pulls. I think that satisfies the definition of predatory.

I was generally aware of rulings here, but looked into examples before posting, so here you go (https://www.asa.org.uk/advice-online/promotional-savings-claims.html):


*"Ads for a mattress sale which stated ““HALF PRICE”, alongside a box with numbers counting down from £399 to £199 were ruled against by the ASA. Over the previous year, the mattress was shown at the higher price for 49.85% of the year, and at the lower price for 50.14%, and the price had alternated between the two each month. Because the promotional periods were essentially equivalent in length to the periods when the full price was charged, the ASA did not consider that higher price was the  established usual selling price (Dormeo UK Ltd, 13 October 2021). Similarly, complaints were received about a sale for Simba mattresses.  The advertiser did not provide the ASA with any pricing history to demonstrate that the usual selling price was genuine, however, the complainant provided screenshots which demonstrated that the reference price of the product had fluctuated over a three-month period, and that the mattress had been on sale for 71% of the year. Therefore, the complaints were upheld (Simba Sleep Ltd, 21 September 2022). See also J Sainsbury plc, 06 June 2018."*

author: stefanmacc
content: If you have a lot of transients happening then try using subtle distortion on the close mics . That same lo fi plug-in can work somewhere between .1 and 2 db of gain.. that will even things out quite a bit. And then use a vca style comp on the overheads or something with a fast attack/release that can take any snare attack out of the OHs. Parallel comp on the drum bus can help too. I do multiple layers of parallel chains on my drum busses… vca compressors with a fast release are fun for this

author: Adam Thein
content: On that note re:pumping maybe worth trying to key sidechain compression off some of your drums on the instruments you want to hear (or feel) pumping on.  Gives you the illusion of slamming a limiter without having to actually do it, while keeping your drum transients under control before the actual limiter.  Volume shapers are great for this (LFO tool, cableguys, Duck, etc) or any good flexible digital compressor with an external sidechain.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s always been: if something is crucial to the vibe of the song, say a certain echo, or dotted stereo delay guitar part, that shit gets printed and sent as an option. But the mixer also gets the rough in case they got a better way to do it. 

That’s why a mixer gets a rough bounce. So they know what to reference. 

CLA used to have a 12 page mix submission requirement thing where you had to consolidate all files, take off all fx entirely, and send him all the tracks bounced from 1 clearly labeled.

Again, it’s CRAZY to me watching a mixer pushback against having to actually mix the song. It’s like someone hiring me to vocal produce and I’m like “cool, but you have to pre record the vocals, compress them right, get the takes, comp em, mix them, and then I’ll… tickle them a little. Where’s my 5k and a point?”

author: Jodonny
content: I'm not sure if this will be helpful to anyone else, but I feel pretttttty dumb after realizing that Dessers do not compress the frequencies you're setting in the plugin. I've heard/seen multiple big mix engineers use these plugins to "just deess the high mids" (3-5k), and never really thought about it.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
First advice is to lean into it. Sound distorted? Distort it more. Overly compressed? Compress it more. That sorta thing helps me a lot.

Second is to detune a little left to right. Hard tuned vocals on the sides tend to get phasey and lean toward the middle. A little detuning will help widen them again. 

Without hearing it none of us can actually diagnose tho right?

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think it’s really important to not confuse a shitty drummer flamming with “phase relationship”. Especially because lining up a snare hit on a live kit to not flam will actually fuck with phase relationships. 

Again the screen shot shows a poor drum hit, not a phase issue per se, which AGAIN was the original point of gaspards post was that he was intermittently flipping phase on certain hits. That’s a very different thing then linking up a snare hit to not flam. 

This kinda feels like when my friend was making a movie and she kept authoritatively and confidently telling the composer to turn down the reverb and after a week in frustration she brought the stems to me and I got to go “oh. You mean tremolo”.

author: Zack Hames
content:
One thing I’ll say, just as a rule of thumb, I really think keeping your faders at 0 or LOWER is ideal. I find I clip the mix bus and my mixes get 2D sounding when I start having to crank everything above 0. If anything needs to be louder than 0, everything comes down instead. (Maybe more of a “newbie” tip if you’re struggling with gain staging)

Really, I want my clip gain levels set so my compressors react predictably. I like as high of levels as I can get at the clip/audio file.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
That said, I have 5 or so compressors that I use on the regular for different things. 

Castelli’s sojourn into ZERO compressors def taught me that sometimes reducing dynamic range is best done without a compressor, but comps almost always impart tone and often I want that. 

So what’s  MY fav? Well, what are we trying to accomplish? 


For clean/creamy I like Kramer PIE
For Crunchy/spitty I like UAD 1176LN
For thick/saturated UAD 175-B
For warm/slow Fairchild 660/70
For detailing trainsient/decay times on drums & guitars I like SPL Transient Designer OR NI Transient Master

author: BatMeckley

But like, how much Rx was done on the vocal in the context of what the conversation has been about, in terms of clip gaining de clicking spectral repair etc.?

author: aidanthillmann
content: I’ve recently been practice mixing against my mentor, and mine have been sounding like a mid range mess, where his had better energy and impact with better space in the mid range for the vocal. I thought I was making things “clearer” by letting the music have a good amount of mid range to poke out, but really I was just covering up the vocal and making a mess, and leaving the low and high end lacking in energy. So my revelation has been to pay better attention to the space that the vocal needs and make sure I’m making the music fit in with the vocal. Also, for me, multiband compression (in tasteful amounts) on the mix buss has been helping both with mid range control and overall better energy.

author: Deleted User
content:
I love midrange mess. 

having good amount of midrange to poke out is the right idea. It just needs to be distributed in a way that makes sense to our ears. 

Low and high end lacking could mean that there’s actually not enough of them, but it could also mean that the midrange isn’t distributed in a way that lets the low end be pushing the speakers and be able to hear the top end *distinctively. 

In terms of midrange distribution, I found it helpful to think about “where do I want this instrument to occupy in the mids?” -> to do this, context is absolutely necessary. I’m not a mixer, but I like to produce with that in mind, and once I get to the mixing process then I listen to the whole thing and start thinking about where I want to put things. 

and then there is this new thing I’m starting to find and explore- “what instruments want to push the speakers together in xHz area?” 

sometimes boosting the same area in two different elements that hit simultaneously help tighten things up and glue things together, rather than everything moving front and back all over the place. 

I used to think everything has to be separated like a jigsaw puzzle, but I’m only starting to realize that not how audio works. these days I’m learning that some things will want to occupy the presence in the same or similar area, and that is the thing that helps the mixes feel more coherent sometimes.

author: Chad Rodgers
content: I always tend to keep it in the same project. In terms of how I go about production vs mixing, sometimes I'll mix as I go (as long as I'm making fast, intuitive decisions and I don't let mixer brain take over this is a good thing as I can end up with a finished product extremely quickly), and sometimes I'll keep going with production and tracking, knowing I'll mix afterwards. Equally it depends if I'm in the room with an artist. They don't want to see me going deep on EQ or saturation moves and wasting their valuable time, so in a session I'll often wait until I'm unattended and I can go deep afterwards.

author: Sam Segarra
content: Pulsar 1178 has a preset called "Over Compressed Acoustic Guitar" - that exemplifies a good starting point for acousticp compression. Essentially medium to high ratio, fast attack, medium to fast relesse and, importantly, cutting a good amount of low end in the sidechain so compression is only triggered by the transients. Any compressor plugin with a fast attack and a comprehensive sidechain should work.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: I don’t know if there’s a right or wrong with this as long as it sounds good. There are mixers I love who have a ton on the master and some who often have almost nothing. Something that gets brought up here a lot around the topic is the ability to have contrast between elements in the mix. Usually that contrast (clean/saturation, bright/dark) is reduced when every element has heavy saturation on it, or the whole songs top end parts are excited from start to finish. With that said I do not fear trying big moves if it sounds cool

author: Ross Fortune
content:
This is good to know. The way I approached it was to build the mix with loads of headroom, then when it was all sitting roughly where it wanted to be, I’d alt+drag the input/output of Saturn to wherever it sounded good. It was usually followed by The Glue or another compressor (not always). When I first started using it I was thinking about where the harmonic stages would happen in a (Un)fairchild. I guess probably pre and post compression? There’s probably arguments to compress pre saturation, but I auditioned compression before and after Saturn and preferred it post on that occasion, so that’s how it stayed in the template.

The Pro-Q curve hedged against a tendency I had/have to mix too smiley, and all in all it seemed to make things sound more gooder so the duo lived on in my template… until it didn’t.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I’ve found that they sound identical as long as the DAW settings are identical (pan law being one of the biggest factors in sonic differences). 

That said, every Daw has its own workflow / “logic” / toolset to it that may cause you to work / think differently. I think this is the most important consideration when choosing a DAW for mixing. What DAW creates the best path between the sound in your head to the sound coming out of your speakers?

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: Brauer told a story about mixing a track that had full arrangement in right from the beginning but the song really felt like it needed to start with just acoustic and vocals to tell the story better. He went ahead and did that, pretty significant changes. But he sits down with the artist and producer on face time and says “so I changed some stuff. Here’s why, and I need you to listen to it 4 times and really consider it”. And that’s what they did, and the artist ended up going with it. But that really only worked the one time, the handful of other times he made his case the artist or producer would say (and rightfully) “I hear what you’re going for……..no”. But I love that he has the conversation about it and really insists on the idea getting its fair consideration

author: cian riordan

author: Slow Hand
content:
I find it's rarely necessary to compress a synthesizer if you're the one programming it. You already have control over the attack/sustain ratio on the instrument using the ADSR controls. And you can balance the harmonics through your choice of filtering or oscillators. Synthesizers rarely have low-level information to be revealed that can't simply be turned up at the source.

Of course, you might want the distortion artifacts from compression, but I'd probably use a saturator module.

That said, if you're a mixer who has received an audio bounce of a synth, then... sure! Compression would be good for balancing poke-y stuff, controlling boomy low-end, or there could be some room tone from a re-amp signal, or some attack that needs to be accentuated. So compress away!

content: Audio interface loopback/virtual IO is going to be your lowest latency and most stable (compared to Aux IO) option but I’m not sure exactly how the symphony implements this. author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
oversampling can have an impact in the sound when you're using a nonlinear process (distortion etc) because it shifts the aliasing out of the audible band, I pretty much never have a use for oversampling something like an EQ, and hardly ever for gentle compression
but the advice here is to choose based on the context, rather than "always oversample to 32x or else because reasons!"

sometimes that aliasing distortion or whatever other stuff is just what that sound needs

try doing some really really crazy settings with unfairchild and then toggling through the oversampling and see if that does anything, if you don't notice a difference you just saved some CPU power

author: Slow Hand
content:
The first thing that comes to mind is that you may be pushing into your master buss limiter too hard. 

How much gain reduction is your limiter currently doing? If you're already pushing aggressively into your limiter and then you're boosting low end *into* it, it's going to keep turning it back down.

If that's what's happening, the answer would be to back off your limiter so that the low end doesn't get compressed.

author: Aric.Edward
content: Hey guys! thought I might ask this here. I am mixing a rock track right now. I was looking into what Michael Brauer does with sending the vocals to multiple different parallel compressors and blending the character of each different compressor into the vocal... do any of you guys do anything like this? and do any of you all have some cool suggestions as far as which compressors might work for this and what kind of character they add to a vocal in parallel?

author: JustinLeu
content:
Keep it as simple as you can = )

Try doing the para processing from 1 send off of the main vocal and then blending the "dry" signal (original) with the wet signal at a vocal bus...

Para sends to try:
1. CLA76 or VU-comp or similar 1176 slamming away 
2. Distortion....so many options but you can try **Decapitator **(there are some great presets for gritty vocals....then just run them 100% wet since it is a send)  or the protools sans-amp

So routing will be:

Original vocal (dialed to roughly fit the track) with a SEND TO:
Para 1 (heavy comp)
Para 2 (disortion)
Bus all those tracks to:
Vocal bus...and on this treat the group as you need (comp,eq,limit,de-ess etc)

author: Aric.Edward
content: I did something like this with the snare drum and it came out pretty cool. I sent drums to like 5 different compressors. a dbx 160 on snare in parallel within the snare bus, then the whole kit minus the OHs sent to 2 different compressors with settings for adding transient impact, and sent also to 2 more compressors that add sustain, that 4th channel is also blown out with devil-loc following the compressor.  but i just kept blending between until i made like my favorite rock snare that i think i have ever done so far lol

author: Aric.Edward
content: Thanks guys! Im gonna get back to this and run my vocal through like 15 compressors right now for science

author: cian riordan
content: I tend to be more of a compressor in sequence guy rather than a in-parallel guy, but there’s really no right answer. My chain usually consists of a character compressor (something doing the heavy lifting tonally), then a utility compressor to level things out a bit more (rvox or an ssl channel) then I’ll bus that and all the lead vocal specific effects into a glue compressor to bind them all together — often unfairchild or SSL bus style. I know the formula well so I can gain stage things quickly and audition a few different things in each position to get the lead right where I want it.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I wouldn’t agree that it’s mere fluctuation or that it means basically nothing. 

A vast majority of sounds specifically go from sharper to flatter over time (energy dissipation reduces the frequency of a vibration) and this is VERY responsible for a sense of impact and the  3-dimensionality of a sound. 

When producing synthetic sounds, shaping the pitch envelope is IMO one of the fastest, most impactful, and most overlooked ways to get them from “meh” to totally fucking sick. Like I’d go as far as to say it’s one of the main separators between intermediate and excellent sound design in electronic music

author: GaspardMurph
content:
Here’s what I do regarding loudness : I try to make the client stems hit my stereo bus around where the red line is by the top of the Mute button (very unprofessional that I don’t know)  - so I usually trim my groups (I have a VCA in my template that controls my different instrument buses’ volume). Usually when getting hot stems it’s around -3 / -4db trim. Rarely I get stems too quiet and in these cases I usually clip gain all stems down. 

Then I usually have ozone vintage limiter on at -2.5db which will add a bit of loudness with the auto gain and then set the maximizer to +2dbs.

By the time I’m done doing my thing with bus processing, eqing etc… I’m usually in a good spot lufs wise and then it’s a matter of turning up or down either the makeup gain on my compressor or the output of the maximized

you’ll get no argument from me on the affect it has on the audio, 1-2db on a limiter or clipper can be barely audible while 1-2db on a traditional “compressor” might change the sound dramatically in a negative way.

Rounding transients is the goal IMO, keeping the impact while reducing the variance like tape, IMO Clippers can sound like the positive affects of tape without the negative

author: Eric Martin
content: Transients don’t get fucked the way I use a compressor on my mix bus, but I’m VERY gentle and rarely get much reduction, almost always open later release faster with a comp that can handle it without too much crunch

author: WHenry
content: Hey y’all - do we have any discussions about dynamic EQ vs Multiband compression?

author: David Fuller
content: well think about it right - a multiband compressor is a frequency limited compressor, and it affects dynamics of a given frequency range. A dynamic EQ is a level affected EQ, and it affects EQ of a given dynamic range. They both basically end up doing the same thing - dynamic control of frequency - but go about it differently.

[Mono vs. stereo samples] Do you sample everything in stereo, or do you sample some things (ex: kick, snare) in mono? If the former, do you later convert kick or snare stereo samples to mono in your DAW?

author: Deleted User
content: Loudness question: I’ve been struggling with drum samples and bass/808s specifically. A lot of these sounds come in so dense and compressed, they sound good in level close to 0dbfs but they don’t have the knock and energy they had when they are turned down to create headroom. Especially when it’s playing with other instruments that are more dynamic. A lot of times they even sound smaller and thinner too. So I’ve attempted using samples that have taller peaks but at the end of the day I end up doing similar treatments (distortion, clipping) to get the level of density and aggression. Which also leads to another question about transient treatments. I’ve watched tutorials on this topic and some people used clipper to have the limiter work less, and the others work slightly differently by preserving the peak and using parallel to create density. I tried both ways, but still left me with the issue of not being able to crank it louder without messing things up. With the dense drum samples, the rest of the mix would start choking every time the drums hit. Generally I find it so much easier to get things to compelling loudness when there’s no drum instrument (I find percussive elements with higher pitches easier to fit in the mix). How can I work around this?

author: Josh
content: I have no clue what your skill/gear level is, but are you sure you can hear everything properly? I had the same issue until I swapped monitors and actually heard what was happening to my 808s and drums. I do a lot of saturation (shout out to Nani) and use ozone’s low end refocus to get the 808 to sit a bit higher so it’s not all muddy.

author: Eric Martin
content: try this next time, when you get that 808/drum sample that sounds good at 0dbFS, turn it down to where you think it needs to be, then turn everything else down also, and turn the speakers up until the loudness of the 808 sounds the same as it did at 0, now start to pull all the other elements into the the mix and balance around that 808 without adding compression clipping or any other effects

author: Deleted User
content: To me personally, throws are more about what effects are followed after. My favorite post delay/reverb effects Unfiltered Audio Byome. For workflow, this is 10/10. It’s a modular multi effect plugin, and making a few different presets on it allows me to quickly switch around between different colors and modulation. It has random parameter set feature and can unexpectedly bring in interesting sounds quickly too. Other than that, I also like Soundtoys stuff for phaser and tremolos, ubermod for chorusing and other phase effects on the delays. For reverb, Dverb is actually pretty cool especially when it’s mixed in with delays. I like Valhalla vintage verb and eventide ultraverb as well. And for post verb or delay saturation, decapitator and spectre. Saturn if I wanna use the dynamics control on it. I also like messing with the polarity, sometimes flipping it can get the presence of the tail heard better without obscuring the dry sound as much.

author: seb
content:
Wow - I just joined this server and Im in love already. What an awesome place to discuss the things I didnt think anyone else was interested in. To add to @cian riordan 's point, it should often be pointed out (as I've seen Matt do a couple times) that the context and type of work someone like Jon Castelli recieves can significantly vary to someone who does low to mid-level type of stuff (bedroom artists, indie artists who are recording on their own or in a studio but with minimal vocal processing). 

I'm sure that with the type of work Jon C is getting that its probably true that he doesn't really need to compress since I'd bet most of the stuff he gets is already 50-60% done. 

If you were watching the Josh Gudwin twitch stream today, then you would've seen another example of this. My guy pulled up the stems, pressed play and there was a literal mixed (albeit improvably so) song coming through. 

tl;dr: just remember that the nature of the audio your working with is likely vastly different than what someone like Jon Castelli is working with. (ie. stems coming in semi-mixed vs. mixing stems that have 0% processing on them)

author: Eric Martin

author: cy (sigh)
content:
0.1 is a percentage as far as i know. The actual amount of saturation deoends both on that the mix knob and the og sources inherent Harmonics that get excited. 

That same amount ona heavy bass won't saturate the same as ona soft flute for example (also depends on the freq  range)

That said I know a lot of mixers that swear by the warm mode on the exciter for even Harmonics And they are very subtle w it.

The eq idk. I'll never really used it but similarly I know a lot of mixers that swear by it. If there's really that much of a difference it's either 1. That's how it is on the eq that it's trying to emulate- it's a vintage style eq, I don't think it's meant to be linear in any way. 

2. There's something wrong w the plug and I'd suggest hitting up support about it.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
specifically when I want to bring that kind of texture up - I'll usually 
1. find the range where it's sitting (soloing the band if needed) , 
2. set a band to that and start processing to get it to sound prominent. 
3. Once dialed in I'll play it w the track and adjust the level of the processed 

Another way would be to use freq specific saturation /distortion to create that texture and then blend it in in parallels.
I would play with more aggressive distortion algorithms in this case

author: Slow Hand
content: It sounds like your 808 is hitting your limiter too hard. Because the limiter has to turn down the entire mix each time that it hits the threshold, all of the music and vocals are being reduced in volume, or "ducked", while the 808 is playing.

author: Kamil
content: The way I used to lower my 808 beforehand was using the slate digital mastering plugin saturation knob

author: Maxim
content: Reason why is because you might be doing things unintentionally to your 808 sound. The image shows you 3 808s. Left is the 808 just clip gained down (what you might want to try for gainstaging into your limiter). Middle is your limiter saturation tactic (which sounds weird to me personally). And right is the same 808 with saturation added in a more thoughtful manner (in parallel just adding upper harmonics that sound better to me).

author: Maxim
content: So unless you’re really looking for that buzzy square wave 808 sound maybe you can view saturation and gainstaging as two different parts of the mixing process

author: Maxim
content: (But even then view the saturation with the limiter as that and not reducing gain)

author: spectrummasters
Eric Martin
content:
right, there was a spectral shaper on low mids on one of his buses, but then again on the mix bus it was doing the 1-6k.

I think from what I understand that JC is doing he is controlling the attack so it’s consistent, then using the transient shaper to make sure it’s the same for every hit. It is smart, and for his workflow it’s also fast and easy.

I use compressors a lot, but I’m also working in mostly indie rock with acoustic drums and bass guitars not 808’s and drum machines, which is a drastically different world. I also think I’m doing what most people don’t do and I don’t always love the artifacts of compression so I generally use slow attacks to maintain transients and fast releases to recover quickly (I adjust so that I get the fastest release before audible distortion)

BTW Bruce Swedien while he may have evangelized not using compression don’t underestimate that his greatest works were done to tape and even when you were conservative and didn’t hit tape hard, the transformers going into tape and out of and the tape as a medium itself would peak limit attack heavy instruments like drums

If doing compression i like the slow attack/fast release compression style , good for you. Get that groove pumping .

author: cy (sigh)
content:
you can send all the drums to an aux post fader so it follows the levels you already have. make sure to follow your panning on the sends 

-then send that aux as a sidechain signal (key in PT) to the compressors on each channel you want affected. adjust the sidechain  level to hit the compressors accordingly and it'll affect each element with all the dynamic interaction.

author: David Fuller
content: LA2A/3A/4 are leveling amplifiers, it's just the 76

author: David Fuller
content: That said, if you wanted to have a limiter in analog, it'd have to be feed forward and probably a FET based  design - the 1176 has a minimum attack time of less than a single sample at 48k but it's a feedback detector. If you could build a feed forward 76 that would probably work

author: Johnny I

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
There’s no wrong way to eat a Reese’s. It all depends on what you’re trying to accomplish! But think of using PP auxes like a Mix Knob. 

As far as vocals, there’s all kinds of ways to do this. I often take a tuned vocal, set the output to a bus that feeds 2 separate auxes with dif types of compression, and then bus both of those back into a single Aux which I treat as if it were the originally recorded vocal track. 

I use spitty 1176 type comp on one and a smoother VariMu type comp on the other, then eq any unwanted resonances and de ess before sending them to the final Aux.
