author: ehutton21
content:
i just realized that i believe we’re talking about two different plugins! im using lift 3, I believe diamond transient is the one with the ability to clip in the mid range. i don’t have transient, but after my experience with using these across my mixes I’m pretty set on adding it to my arsenal. diamond lift 3 sounds big and powerful on bus and mastering duties. there’s a certain heft it adds in the clipping department that my other tools don’t have, but it’s compression and eq moves are actually quite versatile—it can be just as powerful but also surprisingly… musical?

i like compressor mode 3, clipped mode 1, and i gain stage the bus/track so i can drive the input on the plug-in, compress 1-2 db, drive the makeup gain of the compressor into the clipper so i’m on the verge of hitting the overs, then i gain match the plug-in to desired level. maybe add a little saturation there too. it’s got a subtle feel but it’s 👌🏼

my experience with this has been incredible with it on drum bus, music bus (albeit i’m not clipping), and mix bus especially when i get to the stem stage of my work in ableton (i do some stem work in ableton after doing the heavy lifting stuff in protools). pure insanity. 

i’m pretty disappointed that even with my mac m1 studio, acustica plugins in protools aren’t really running for me. gonna have to troubleshoot that.

author: ehutton21
content:
agree with multiband for problematic performances and/or songs where the artist is craving a super compressed aesthetic (some of the electronic/industrial influenced pop/hip-hop type stuff). i’ve seen success with three bands for hyper compressed vox—one for low information (100Hz and below), then one from there to 1k, and then one more for everything above 1k. that’s the default in MC404 

MBs are kinda hard to rationalize for me on most anything else outside of sound design, which is part of what i think people (at least some of my people) want. MBs are great for really handling what you don’t want in a sound or over pronouncing something for effect though, IMO. if i need to really kill a region of like low mids, i can obliterate anything with pro-mb. dynamic eq way more precise but also better gentle for gentle strokes.

author: rse
content: Something has been bugging me a little since I've found a lot of contradictory information on the topic. I will try to describe what I think will happen, correct me if I'm wrong. When I send a signal out to a parallel compression track, compress it and then EQ, that EQ will be in parallel to the main signal. Since EQ causes fase shift this could create problems (I think?). I've noticed from doing some test and research that bell and shelve curves wouldn't really have any weird behaviors in this case, only that bell curves would have a slightly different Q and shelves would be shifted up or down in frequency ever so slightly. Filters seem to be where the real problems are, since they introduce a full 180° phase rotation in the frequency area around the cutoff (i forgot where exactly) kinda similar to what an all pass filter would introduce but with added shift below or above the cutoff frequency depended on HP or LP. So bell and shelve curves should behave very predictably, but filters would behave in more unexpected ways. It's all kinda messy in my head because of different information sources. The internet is an amazing place but it's really hard to get good, clear and correct information sometimes.

From my experience; 1. re-record 2. try to get it out with whatever you have, Rx, spl de-verb, waves ns1 and clarity vx, whatever tools you can think of. 3. Since it's REALLLLLY verby, just run with it. If it's impossible to rerecord or to polish it up with any tools you have, it's best to just go with that sound imo. Edit: use as little compression as possible, you don't want to be bringing out all that nasty verb even more

author: rse
content: A hard clipper will behave differently than the digital clipping that occurs when you clip your converters or when you export a signal that exceeds 0db at a bit depth of 24bits. Your daw works internally at 32bits floating point, which means that your individual faders will have a lot of headroom above 0 db, so you can go pretty much as high as you want with them, as long as you turn the signal down in a later stage before it hits the final output. Otherwise you will be clipping your converters like you said. This clipping will be different for every converter, and it's why mastering guys buy converters that are worth more than your car, just so they can get a certain flavour when clipping their a/d (although I'm pretty sure most have stopped doing this, because it often just sounds like shit lmao). Clipping your signal with a plugin will introduce different distortion/saturation/artifacts. It will even be different between different plugins and between different algorithms inside of those plugins (if you are able to select those)  (some clipping plugins actually use the exact same algorithms, so those won't have any differences ofc. EDIT: the only differences here would be in the oversampling functionality etc. of the plugins used, not in the actual clipping algorithm. There actually aren't a lot of hard clipping algorithms out there, so most differences between plugins will be in the way the anti-aliasing filters work)

author: BillyC
content: I just import some VCAs, FX returns, mix bus, and print track. All other routing is only done as needed, because routing decisions are really about processing. And those decisions are hard to make until I’ve heard the song and can see what stems I have to work from. I’ve just gotten too many sessions from people where there is so much bussing and subgrouping going on that by the time the vocal gets to the mix bus, it is passed through 3 instances off gullfoss and 4 different compressors and there is zero life in it. It quickly gets out of control. I actually find minimal bussing to be a quicker workflow because I don’t have to follow a whole series of subgroups to know the entire processing chain on a given audio source when I’m trying to make a tweak, nor will that tweak affect any other element that is sitting just fine. That’s just my brain though.

author: ehutton21

author: ehutton21
content:
Tools like soothe2, pro-q3, spectral shaper, are absolutely essential when I work with poor recordings and they’re frequently used in my chain. 

With soothe, i use it because I hate resonance hunting in pro-q, so I’ll set up a soothe2 band with the mix at 50% which is limiting GR to like 6.0db with a selectivity of above 5.0 and a sharpness ~5-6. Listen, solo delta, hunt till satisfied, repeat. Spectral shaper at 0.0, attack and release close around 10-15 in light and im knocking a 1-2dbs off in the low mids usually (which doesn’t require a harsh threshold), and maybe another spectral shaper that’s broadly working from 2k-6k (esp on the NT1A) is essential. MC404 is great for proximity effect, i set the bands to rel. 2 mode and filter 100Hz and below, compress 100-1k for about 2-3 dbs of GR, and hit 1k onwards with 1-2db.

author: ehutton21
content: I have my vintech patched in to my I/O as like insert 3. Set a vocal preamp like it’s going to line, right, and you’re pretty much getting what you have ITB and running it through your transformers like you would if you had been there with the preamp. I’ve tried to read into this and the most I got was a GS thread about whether or not it degrades audio quality, and whatever I lose by running it through my preamp and distressor, I make up for in comfort and tonal familiarity. It won’t be a silver bullet but it’ll give you a blanket of “oh yeah ok I have this sound, that’s my transformer, I can work with that” and it isn’t necessarily a radical move like distortion

author: ehutton21
content: I also feel like Oxford inflator does something on budget vocal mics that gets them closer to “expensive” saturation than my other tools tbh

1. A tiny tick (door slamming)
2. A period of steady midrange (the room verb)
3. The whoosh of the entire noise floor and A/C unit rushing in to fill the vacuum. 😆

author: Jeremy Klein

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
High passing the vocals right below the fundamental shouldn’t kill any low end thickness- if anything it’ll give you a little hump there. 

There are a lot of compressors that add low end resonance, some more musical than others. UAD 175-B and Fairchild do really well with that for my taste. 

Bottom without woof and top without sibilance are what make your vocals sound pro, and there’s no one way to skin that cat properly.

author: Adam Thein
content: Anybody care to share any favorite 1176 settings?  I feel like I'm always reaching for it for the 4:1 slowest attack fastest release thing on vocals but I rarely use the higher ratios or all buttons in.  What sources are you all reaching for an 1176 when mixing specifically with the higher ratios?

author: Will Melones
content: I pretty much only use an 1176 as a transient shaver or for effect, so sometimes it’s just a really high ratio with fastest attack and release just for the distortion

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Settings change per source for me- but I generally reach for it when I’m looking for a real snappy electric or spitty vocal. I’m pretty partial to the UAD 1176 over CLA or BF, but I love the UAD 176 and 175-b when I’m looking for extra sauce… the more you drive those the better they sound, and it’s hard to make it too pumpy, whereas the 1176 it’s hard to make it *not* pumpy. That’s just me though. I’ve been accused of not going hard enough more than I have of going too hard, so keep that in mind.

author: Will Melones
content: I only ask because I've had that experience of 1176ing on the way in and coming back a day later to hear that take-killing distortion. Like who recorded this traaash, oh it was me?

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, because what else am I doing right now, I’ll tell you a real fun tip about 1176’s: they tend to have a real magic sweet spot, much like the way a good guitarist sets their amp for just the edge of breakup. The track comes alive with harmonics without being “woah that’s distorted”, and I’ve always viewed them more for that effect rather than just a “gain controller”If you have your own 1176 that you can really spend time with, you can figure out just where in the needle that magic happens. THEN you can use something ultra transparent and awesome like a Dave Hills titan to control dynamic on the way in and really increase your chances of keeping the vocal right in the magic spot without risking overs. 🪄 You can do it with a studio’s 1176, you just have to figure out the sweet spot before the artist gets there and be willing to adjust on the fly

author: Will Melones
content: So this is really how much signal you're putting into it, and how much you push that input knob, not so much how it hits the threshold or what ratio you set.

author: BatMeckley
content: Both! The ratios all sound pretty different to me. Often times I’ll hit the 8 or 12 cause they sound leaner and you. Do. Not. Need. As. Much. Low. End. In. Your. Vocal. As. You. Think.

author: Deleted User

pitch drift is fixes the overall picture of pitch deviation and stabilizes it if there’s a spot where the singer didn’t take enough breath and the note kind of wanders around in pitch. modulation just changes the amount of pitch deviation. 

the problem you described usually occurs to me when I have to fix the notes quite a bit, and the pitch between the connecting notes have to spread apart a fair bit. That’s when dividing it up and moving the blobs to draw in smooth transition between the notes help. Attack time is what I use if I need further smoothing between those divided blobs

author: spectrummasters
content: I can relate to this . I think first impression notes are a great tool and I’m challenging myself to “do less “ not more to roughs:demos . Often times when I’m tracking vocals it is to a two track (rnb/hip-hop) and I’ve learnt that just about any “vocal sound “ I want to go for I better get it whilst we are tracking because the artists always want a rough vocal mix to go away with at end of session . Invariably , whatever that rough sounds like I can’t stray away from (for good or bad ) once they’ve heard it . And then when it comes to a final mix , it gets even more complicated getting the actual stems for the two track and mixing it all down with the vocal tracks as it often (imo) sounds better but doesn’t feel the same as that on the day rough vocal mix to the two track . I realised there’s no way I can get an artist to unhear that first  rough mix and I’m wasting hours mixing it all over again with the stems , like I’m re inventing a wheel no one wants . I’ve noticed @Bainz_  telling @oaklandmatt he had the same issues with thugs punk album and also have heard Jason Goldberg and Stuart white embracing the idea that you’re possibly mixing the final mix/pre master as you track . It’s a very raw and quick approach and it does keep you miles away from overmixing something . I embraced it as a workflow only recently and it’s less stressful than working your ass off on a “perfect” mix only to get back they prefer the vibe of the first day mix .   top tips not to overmix I am meditating on currently are : don’t lose your dynamics , watch your phase relationships don’t change , leave some mistakes in , automate more than compress and be quick

author: ALXCPH
content:
Noticed something funny. The slowest attack on a SSL GComp is 30ms. 
30 ms is around 33hz, which is around 1 full cycle of the lowest perceivable musical note for us (B0). 

I wonder if thats why that setting is so popular. allowing a full cycle to develop, will lets us hear that pure sinewave without distortion while still compressing. 

You could make presets for attack settings for all the 12 notes in the lowest octave. To always have the fastest attack that lets through at least one cycle of the lowest note in the song/key. 

I wonder if Letting the tempo decide the release to dictate the kind of groove/feel the song has. Maybe a Rythmic value? a 16th? and 8th? swung 16th or 8th? 

Food for thought. I know "use your ears" and i do, always. but i just noticed that i and others gravitate towards settings that land around these points of interest and or their multiples.

content: saturation does behave differently, like if you are saturating your bass and drums together. but you can fix that by sidechaining your saturation plugin to both tracks and butting the plugin on each track. that way you will get the stems reacting like they were processed together but still printed individually

author: Deleted User
content:
Same here. And I also went on no compressor route, not only because Jon said he doesn’t use one but I’ve had similar experiences as Jon of running things through compressors to be either disappointed or to be unsure if it was better or not. 

I started using compressors again at some point but I found better tools to achieve what I was hoping to get out of using a compressor through the process of not using any compressor. Now I grab compressor only when I want compressor pump/pinch or tame pokey transients without adding too much harmonics. 

During the early phase of this, I was going overboard with saturation and driving stuff and started dialing back a bit.

Cian’s mix bus curve and saturn preset changed the way I mix, I’m now less heavy handed and can start from a place of having things sound pretty good- but I do end up having to bypass or back off on them every now and then. 

Trying these things made me occasionally deliver something weird at first but in the big picture, they benefited me.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Are they apparent when all of the mics are in? Sometimes that stuff is better addressed on the bus. Have you engaged drum bus processing (if any)? Sometimes thickening and/or darkening the drum bus (Pultec 100Hz, Studer Tape, whatever) renders this upper mid/high stuff less abrasive.

Sometimes addressing too much of this stuff sucks life out of drums. I leave most mad snare ringing in as I work on the drums - it often winds up being cool stuff to add to the pumping energy with heavier parallel compressors, or distortions.

Is it apparent/interfering with the mix as a whole?

author: Slow Hand
content: A simple varispeed re-pitch is the least lossy. The tradeoff is that the formant is shifted downward and the length increases. However, the shifted formant might be fine for your needs, and if you want to maintain the original sample-length you can then use a granular time-stretch algorithm to compress the time back to it's original length.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Any tips for very softly sung breathy vocals?  The ratio of breath sound to actual harmonic content is almost 50/50 on these softly sung female vocals I'm working on and wondering if there's a way to accentuate the harmonic content especially in the mids without accentuating the breath through that range?

Some things I've tried:

Accentuating lows brings up the muddy breath noises from proximity effect
Saturation and compression both lower the dynamic range between harmonic to breath further

author: LAPhill
content:
To @Deleted User 's question about separating articulations: Yes and no. If you're working with a Hans Zimmer style production, the orchestra will record a separate pass of long notes (everyone on the melody/chords) and a pass of shorts (ostinatos and riffs). So if the parts are really that distinct, especially if they overlap, then it makes sense to deliver them split. 

I have longs and short notes split to different inputs in Cubase so that I can get granular with how much reverb to add (longs usually need a little bit more to help glue the transitions together), but if they're meant to be performed as a single line, then I would deliver it merged. Does that make sense?

author: cuba1956
content:
Dear friends, I have a question about sidechain in the stereo compression. Probably a weird one, but I think I'm missing something.
I've been looking into SSL Bus comp schematic — there are several going around the internet and based on what I see in SSL 500 unit are quite interesting in a way how the sidechain envelope follower is generated.
There are several approaches I see in various models:
1. Original SSL mixes left and right channels with OR principle — basically the envelope is generated based on the strongest signal coming from either L or R channels. 
2. Some of the models suggest mixing left and right channels — essentially you get the average signal between channels which is then generates into an envelope.
3. True stereo (or rather dual mono with a single set of settings) — which calculates envelopes for the left and right channels independently.
Some SSL comp models have a switch to trigger between various modes, but if I understand correctly, none of the SSL original models have used true stereo (fully independant) sidechain processing.

author: Deleted User
content:
I find that delays can take some aggresive EQs depending on the style. Give a wild boost on area where I want the delay to cut through and turn the overall delay down - and then compress it a little bit to duck it. 

At least for reverb- I find it’s not always necessarily to have a dry signal keying the compressor to duck the reverb.  Sometimes just a compressor directly on the channel will do something similar and less dramatic than ducking if that’s what is needed for the song, 

Also I find faders very helpful in automating effects. Because I don’t always want them to duck in the same shape or ducking is something I’d do to change the nature of the tail and will still need some additional shaping to give specialness to different moments.

For vocals I like copying the audio track and make separate fx tracks because I only want it on certain words. Even for overall effect, I use a separate track so I can take out certain words from reverb or clip gain them. Or even fade in words when I don’t want the early part of reverb poking out too much in certain parts.

author: stefanmacc
content:
There are others here that can probably answer this better. But IMO you don’t want to rely on the limiter as a way to achieve loudness or excitement in a mix because you’ll likely end up with a crushed muddy mess… The limiter is not very good at those jobs.

Also LUFS is perceived loudness meaning EQ plays a huge role in that.. Distortion / Saturation plays a big role..  

So limiting should be one slice of the pie when it comes to achieving level… the rest should be done within the mix with the correct EQ moves . Correct distortion and some compression (not too much)

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I do a LOT of these. Couple things that help me:
Dynamics are your friend in arrangements like this. No need to use compression to bring things forward cause there’s only two things right?
I end up spending most of your time cleaning things like mouth noises, detailing esses, string squeal, etc. 
FX tend to be obvious in these contexts so the work is to be subtle.
Also cian & Jack are spot on IMO.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I know I am not a mixer, but I get mixes that sometimes have HUGE transient peaks…I can tell the mixer thought “I want the drums to hit, turn it up”…but then wants the master loud.

So what happens? I limit, squashing the transients down to get us loud. Which is just accomplishing turning down the drums, but with less transient detail (of course it does some other things, just generally).

Point is, they could just turn down the drums 2db, keep the detail, and that balance would actually get us LOUDER in the long run

Anytime I’ve gotten a record loud & good it was from the mixer handling a lot of the dynamics and excitement within the mix, not from the limiting

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Whatever is necessary. I have done unspeakable things, and sometime damn it’s a vibe…one I was smashing like 6 db, 8db, even 10 between a couple limiters. But that is rare. And I’m also often having to get tricky with compression, specifically in the lows etc.

More often I just gain them down in RX, the wild peaks. If they aren’t useful or musical

These are all bandaids, and not ideal case things. Sort of to a point I made before where most of the things I’m doing are not very useful to mixers, but the perspective I think is

I like to put an ssl-g comp style channel strip plug with eq, gating, and compression specific to the kick in and kick out, very subtly use standard clip to taste on each of the two (or not/or later on the bus) and bus those both to a kick bus where I’ll do some additive eq and a tiny bit of compression and then bounce it down to just one kick track once the balance between them is set and the character of the sound is together.
I find it’s nice to have the kicks all one aux and it’s easier to control the sound as one without dealing with different mic sources and sometimes it’s nice to not even route the kick bus to the drum bus, depending on the song and desired effect.

author: peterlabberton
content: Yeah, the way I've seen it (and am dragging my feet to start doing on scores) is each group has its own aux, and that aux has (say) a compressor and an EQ on it. Each aux has the identical comp and EQ, and all are grouped. So then you can treat it *like* a more traditional 2bus, but then hit commit to last insert when you're done, and that's it. All these auxes just go through one limiter on the actual master. Of course, you don't get the effect of the proper sidechain on compression this way, but it seems like a decent compromise.

author: LAPhill
content: Careful about side-chain compression in a score mix. As you likely know, the reason to deliver stems is because things change in the dub. I've seen directors just straight-up mute stems and wildly change levels. If your now-exposed stem is pumping and reacting to something that's not there, it can be quite strange.

I now see how that extra octave on the top really does add something I wasn't putting in there.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Twas me...VU meters are very useful tools because of their relative nature. If you know where the sweet spot of a compressor is on a drum bus for example, you can calibrate 0 on the VU meter to that sweetspot. then mixing into your compressor isn't such a guessing game every time (because you get the needle bouncing around 0, not too far under or not too far over). 

i use a digital one on the way out when i'm hitting my analog chain so everything goes out at the relative same level. i use an analog one on the way back in calibrated to a "safe" level and i know when it's coming back in ultra hot or i need a little extra gain to get it to the sweet spot. when you're monitoring stays at a consistent level, VU meters can help you judge relative relationships quite easily. i could see it being useful in the use case you described if you've calibrated the VU accordingly. say you want to generally hit -10 at the mixbus...calibrate a -10 signal to 0 on the VU. everything you then feed into the mixbus will show on the VU + or - where you want to end up.

author: stefandurandt
content: I use an Analog VU meter on the output of my monitor controller built by the inhouse tech who also worked at Neve (he designed and built the 8816 summing box) - he recommended the Sifam ones because their ballistics are really good - which I think is the main argument for analog vs digital. I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. After that I also got another 2  lessons by 301 mastering engineers (one who’s won like 19 aria - australian grammies & been nominated for like 90) - once where I gave a floortom too much bottom end $ & that really triggered a mastering compressor limiting him in some way & he showed me how the left side jumped on the vu - I didn’t hear it at all in the mixing room but could hear it clearly in the mastering room. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: stefandurandt
content: The one I have has two settings - -18 (like on analog gear - consoles, compressors etc) which is pinned all the time on modern loudness but the 2nd setting I’ve set to -7 which is way more useful.

author: rse
content:
hi guys, haven't been here in a while. I have a specific question regarding asymmetrical waveforms. I've heard that very often brass instruments like trumpets and also male vocals can produce these sort of waveforms.
I'm working on a male vocal pop ballad and the vocal is quite asymmetrical, i'm concerned this will mess with compression and limiting and the overall loudness I will be able to get. I have "corrected" the asymmetrical waveform using phase rotation in rx. Is it common practice to use phase rotators/all-pass filters to make these waveforms more symmetrical? or do these things do more harm than good? what are your approaches to this? Thanks a lot
videos on the subject: https://youtu.be/dAzjq6vldkc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nSV5ocyfKLA

author: rse
content:
from my own tests on different material I've noticed that phase rotation actually changes the transients and can introduce something that looks very similar to preringing to me, so I'm very hesitant to use it on something like drums, but i'm not sure if this is a concern on vocals.
I mostly just want to know if this is something that is done in professional mixes (to make sure the vocal has a little bit more room before it hits a compressor threshold) or not

author: rse
content: it doesn't hit the limiter hard no, but was concerned about how the compressors on the vocal track itself would react to this kind of waveform, as I've never dealt with these before and I'm not extremely confident in my own listening skills

author: Ross Fortune
content:
[Apologies for long message, I’m thinking out loud but also detail is probably useful] Gearing up to mix a live album with a heap of songs (tbc but potentially 23 in one show).

The last time I did something like this, it was low channel count -   a couple of acoustics, one or two vocals, maybe a keyboard per song. I mixed the whole thing in one Pro Tools session, with a separate set of channels for each song which I’d then make inactive and move onto the next song. When printing the continuous mix at the end, I’d make active two songs at a time for any overlap, and constructed the long printed mix like that.

In this case though, there are multimiced drums, bass, electric guitars, keyboards, vocals. The recordings are good (from the stereo board mixes I’ve heard) and the scale is such that I want to have the fidelity I’d approach a studio record with, and the room to shape an identity for each song (while still sounding like they all happened on the same stage on the same night) so I’m thinking to use my usual elaborate drum mix routing with parallels etc, all the bells and whistles.

This complexity would put me off mixing 23 songs in one session, but I’m thinking of the inevitable crunch at the end of the project and the potential frustration of jumping between sessions.

Am I thinking too deeply about this? Should I just get a drum sound and leave it there for 23 tracks, with a few rides here and there?

Not much experience with this stuff so any thoughts would be very welcome please!

author: GaspardMurph
content:
In my experience they are quite used ! Many TV shows in France and Europe require TV tracks or PBOs (play back orchestra) as we call them here. A lot of newer developing artists don’t have budget for MDs that can prep a TV track, and aren’t very good with DAW to make it out of stems. Obviously this is very genre specific to variety / pop / hip hop. Most rock, indie, folk people don’t need these as these TV shows aren’t really part of their promo circuit. 

I have been called many times to deliver a new TV track with a specific timing edit if a specific program has a maximum length of day for example 2:20m.

I usually make the TV track this way:
- instrumental
- background vocals
- lead vocal throws 
- maybe lead vocal in on choruses minus 5/6 dbs

I have been advised by sound folks in TV / Radio not to master TV tracks. Something about loudness requirements, TV broadcast compressors and being able to mix the live vocals more easily with a less compressed and more dynamic TV track.

author: cian riordan
content: The term 'glue' gets thrown around a lot and it's probably the most apt way of describing it. Even well mixed tracks can have a disconnected feeling if everything is able to be fully dynamically independent of the other elements -- this is where bus compression can be useful. It's just an additional flavor that can enhance the mix depending on how you use it.

content: Another question, why is SSL Bus Comp so popular for mix bus compression?

author: Joshua Riley
content:
Hype, marketing and nostalgia

In all seriousness, I’ve never worked on an SSL console but my view is that it’s popular today because many engineers back in the day worked on SSL consoles and the bus comp was built in. With all that audio summing through the console, you’re inherently going to get some sort of glue/cohesion with all that analog goodness in the console and then the bus comp was that final little element that had a way of glue-ing it all together

author: Joshua Riley
content: So while the bus comp may give some sort of vibe/glue to a mix but not in the full way of having a full console like they did which is where all the hype comes from

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So yes, the consoles (E/G particularly) had a thing with all the VCAs and FET switching, but even in isolation the compressor is special IMO

author: NoahNeedleman
content: A LOT of compressor plugs add sub harmonic frequencies. That *can* be a problem but isn’t one inherently. High passing then creates another set of *possible* problems, that aren’t *necessarily* problems.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Those are typically harmonics caused by non linear processes (compression/clipping/limiting). They are present all the way up the spectrum but masked by signal. You see them at the very top on an FFT or RX because there is no or less signal to mask them

author: Adam Thein
content: This has been stuck in my head for a bit - isn't this normal behavior for most compressors?  The longer the attack time, the less gain reduction, because the compression effect takes longer to reach full ratio and before it can it's already switched back to the release stage of the circuit because the signal has gone back below the threshold?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I'm used to that with the *ratio* on an SSL, but it's not the intended or expected behavior of the attack time.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I don't do a ton of referencing while mixing anymore but it definitely was and still is a key for learning new things.

I mostly work with young indie artists and producers who are still finding their sound and it's very common for me to get notes like "can we make the guitar solo sound like XYZ song from ABC artist," and usually after a little bit of frustration I work my way through to a new trick up my sleeve by dissecting a sound and trying to recreate it.

I think the major pitfall to avoid though for mixers and producers just at the beginning is understanding that you can't squeeze blood from a stone - not getting discouraged or into the pit of despair if your bedroom produced track with amp sims and samples isn't standing up against the big budget Studio A level records.  But that doesn't mean you can't start learning what a great bass tone is in a mix and why it's working by listening to those intently.

author: river
content:
As I like to mix loud, I take inspiration from a method I found called "clip to zero" when it comes to returns/buses/groups (I'll name them buses.)
And also Skrillex and his crazy groups. He showed his screen for a music video a while ago so it's prolly changed but still gave me inspiration.

It'll look something like
Drum bus + drum room bus, grouped together = drum sum bus.
Synth bus  + synth FX bus = synth sum bus
Vocal bus + vocal fx bus = vocal sum.

If it calls for it and I'm feeling spicy, have another group which contains just my bass elements as their own sum group.

Depending on the track, and how important I think any single element is over the other, I might do something like further group/bus together my drums and synths. Leaving me with 2 buses to balance against each other.

author: Maxim
content:
“The Inflator is not the same as the Enhance feature in the Oxford Limiter, although the effects might be considered similar. In simple terms, the Inflator is a special kind of distortion generator which has no dynamic activity over time. It's a static process. It gives the impression of loudness by providing the harmonic cues we associate with loud and stressed sounds, increasing the harmonic density of the material in a way that is sympathetic to the ear.

The Oxford Limiter's Enhance function is a special kind of 'dynamic' process that does not add distortion to steady state signals. It works over time, programme history, peak and average levels and left/right stereo differences to limit the signal and squash peak events, while providing the listener with the impression that the peaks are still there. It can sympathetically remove peak events so that you can provide more transparent limiting, or make the programme even louder without causing sample value overs.”

author: Maxim
content:
And from the manual:
“The enhance process improves the perceived loudness and presence of the programme material by modifying the dynamic and harmonic content of the signal. Since the method used is different from the Pre-Processing section, it can further enhance the perceived volume of a previously processed signal, while suppressing all signal overloads. As the limiting action does not involve conventional sample value clipping, harsh distortions are avoided, and programme detail and dynamic information is largely retained.

Also, since the plug-in has internal headroom, transient levels greater than notional maximum modulation can pass from the Limiter section into the enhancement stage. This means that percussive overshoots, that would normally be lost in a conventional limiter (or would give rise to overloads), may be included within the sonic results of the plug-in, producing both richer dynamic sonic detail and a useful reduction in the perceived artefacts of the limiting process, all without giving rise to any sample value overload.

This property enables slower attack times to be used in the Pre-Process section, without creating output overloads, which would otherwise result in a need to reduce output levels.”

author: shaunobi
content: Kinda like the triangular or square mics from Sweden, I feel like Sanken is a whole different genetic family of mics. They're design to reduce off-axis coloration, which is interesting. I don't talk about them much because I don't own and have never used one in person, but I'm fascinated by them. (and Pearl, and Milab, and a few others). I build DIY mics from kits and mod existing mics and those diaphragms are all pretty standard, and derivative of old german mics in basically almost all cases. And the diaphragms dominates the sound... it's just fascinating to see a company like Sanken say "let's put two capsules in a body, optimized for lows and highs, and a crossover" and have it work so well.

author: aidanthillmann
content:
I could foresee an issue of fairness here though. Let’s say a producer hires me specifically just to consult, take a look at their session and we tweak together then master, but I think their mix is at a 60% and they think it’s at a 95%. That could of course be a conversation and I could possibly convince them to pay a full mix rate if I say I can make it a lot better, but if they’re really hanging on to their mix and don’t want me to change too much, then I feel I can’t do my job and I might not even want to be credited. At that point it’s just a business transaction and not a true collaboration. 

I can just see some trickiness here for mixers specifically. For mastering engineers it’s a great deal if they get a higher rate and more control over the session, but for mixers it just really depends on the situation. And for people like Jon and Cian to accept half their rate or less when they can pull their normal rate most of the time…I don’t know where the line is. Of course for long time friends and collaborators with high levels of trust, that could be arranged.

Super open to thoughts about this, I’m not closed off to the idea at all, it is totally the right move at times with producers who genuinely take the mix really far!

author: JustinLeu
content:
Everything @Edward Rivera mentioned. It is a very helpful tool, but I think it can be abused and yield a terrible result even if the waveform looks "nice and even" haha.... For instance, you are seeing a waveform that is made of the entire frequency spectrum and the amplitude will be different depending on the sound/frequency makeup of each word. When you just "make it look even" and play it back, many times it sounds worse than before. Full-band and multi-band compression+saturation can sound much more natural, and is wayyyy less time consuming. You are able to get a result very quickly and remain objective. 

Clipgain is very useful...just something to be aware of!

author: Slow Hand
content:
Question for y'all who've worked in TV audio before:

I've got a gig writing several 90 sec tracks for a TV program. I'm writing half-a-dozen ballroom tracks (ballroom as in drag) for their queens. So the gig is calling for club music. My question is this: Should I mix these records like they're an album cut (read: loud/hot) or should I approach the mix knowing that there's going to be available headroom in the TV audio mix?

It's been my experience that loud/squashed records end up sounding puny in TV programming because the broadcast mixers turn it down. If I mix them hot they'll sound banging on set while they're filming, but this may be at the expense of impact in the final broadcast mix when it's turned down.

author: chrissorem
content: Sounds like an orchestration issue. My first thought would be what was the intent of this part and where will anyone be able to hear this properly? If that’s out of your hands not much you can do other than try to saturate and pull harmonic information out of it. author: Chad Rodgers
content:
Weird thing happening. Mixing a production I’ve been working on where a drummer has recorded the drums remotely and sent stems to me. Everything looks fine, but on the last chorus it gets weird. The snare disappears behind the kick when they hit simultaneously. It doesn’t do it elsewhere in the track and I’m unsure as to why. 

Could this be some kind of phase cancellation? Frequency masking? I’ve tried to do some sidechaining, dynamic EQ work and flipping the phase but it doesn’t quite do the trick. Almost at my wits end so any pointers for further exploration appreciated! Cheers!

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
Still sounds thin overall when I crank. Gaining it up only helps marginally and isn’t really doing the trick.

Good call on compression etc, I’ll take a look. I’m very lightly running it through an API 2500 but will bypass it to see if that makes a difference. I’m back on it later this afternoon so will check then 🤞

author: Chad Rodgers
content: Okay so I figured it out and I also awarded myself the dumbass of the year award whilst I was at it… my Pro-G wasn’t gating out some heavy cymbal bleed on the tom mics at the end when it gets a bit gnarlier, so the compressor sucked it all up and made the snare obsolete in the frequencies. Note to self: don’t rush, check the basics before panicking 😅

author: Soundswithsammy
content: Hey All! My Mixbus chain has been a combination of the god particle limiter, and Ozone 11 and sometimes a Fabfilter L2 after, but usually just the God Particle to an Ozone. I've noticed lately, that when I go God Particle to Fabfilter L2, the sides of the music push out significantly more. I've been getting more clarity in the instrumentation of my mixes. The compromise is less saturation, but I think I like the separation (the fabfilter or Ozone limiter was only ever doing 1-2dB of work, but still completely changing that final spectrum. I'm having trouble telling how soon my mixes overload with the Pro L-2 unfortunately. Do you think wider is better? or is a trick and it's too wide, and all that width is overload? I have trouble detecting overload in my Insight2 Plugin, I only notice it on phone speakers after the fact. any advice to help decide?

Different limiter plugins react differently to mixes but it’s good to recognise the artifacts you are hearing

author: chrissorem
content: No worries.  Yes frequency masking or congestion is like two people talking at once at the same volume. Your Brain interrupts this as blurry and confusing. That’s fine if you want it to sound unison. But if the goal is clarity and separation then you need to find a place where one isn’t in the way of the other. I like to think of this as guiding the ear. Example: I’d like to hear the vocal close but I want to feel longer.  In this instance I’d use pre delay in the reverb and darken the reverb  to achieve this.

author: Deleted User
content:
Question for those who use Low bus to compress kick and bass together:

what kind of gain reduction are you doing? and how much?

I did a parallel on UAD 33609 and it felt pretty nice, the kick and the bass was feeling a little too over taking and parallel compression allowed me to tuck it back a little without losing their presence. 

So I was curious if anyone is doing something different on the low bus and why

author: spectrummasters
content: ...im aiming for the dynamic range between the moments where the kick and bass hit seperately...to when they hit together....to be my low end dynamic overall (if that makes sense)....so i dont want to flatten that range there....and instead prefer to compress the kick and bass seprately on their own buses . Im using parrallels of my kick and bass to get my loudness and harmonics, pre Low End Bus . If id want more control id consider a hz-dependent side chain on the bass from the kick, but dont like how that f's with the attack of the bass. Trying to do less processing at all stages......and get there with better balancing ..... So...a tiny bit of  comp on the kick and bass buses (0.5 db slow attack, fast release...usually neutron comp) and only an eq and standard clip on the kick bass bus to only catch random peaks and not jam the final  limiter . i like a littler expansion also , playing around with the pro G expnasion mode is fun

author: BoozleBAM
content: Probably some type of "exciter" and maybe a little bit of compression inherent in the "circuitry" somewhere. Waves has a proprietary something or other in all their plugins that gives them the Waves "sheen." This is all just conjecture, though.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I'm glad that you mention the 0.5 dB here. See, here's my thing with compression: I do like to absolutely smash my bass with compression because I like the sound of a really pinned down bass, and vocals is a given, but other than those two sources, I really don't compress. What I've found is that once I compress one thing,  I find myself going,  "Oh, this thing needs to be brought up, and then this thing and then this thing..." and then I end up in a "loudness war" with myself. I know tons of people who compress the day lights out of everything, and more power to them. Sometimes I wish I could make it work for me... I also find compression somehow takes away from the impact of things as well, in a way.

author: BoozleBAM
content: What I WILL DO, however, is parallel distort things sometimes if I need them to cut, and I guess distortion is an extreme type of compression, so maybe I'm actually compressing MORE than most people. Lol.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Id be happy to listen as well bro! Hard to say what will be right without hearing it.

-EQ and levels are a given...so apart from that...
-Light ratio compression on busses + master (light ratio like 1.25-2:1 allows you to keep things in compression and still feel natural)
-Purposeful reverb/delay to make a believable space 
-Don't be afraid to try a short verb on the 2bus
-Stages of saturation

The biggest thing for sparse/soft arrangements is making the space it lives in believable (if it supposed to feel natural)

author: JustinLeu
content:
Clippers can be great on busses. Great on drums etc… I find Standard Clip to be super intuitive to use and you can visualize what is happening. (Probably helpful if you are trying to gain understanding)

On the mixbus it can be helpful before the limiter but most of the time I would introduce it towards the end of a mix if at all. I would try hard clipping or a more gentle knee and see if between that and a limiter I can get something better than limiting alone.

Keep in mind that any saturation plugin (tube/tape) on the mix bus is “clipping” (soft clipping) and I find that gain staging in to that type of processing is more friendly to mix in to rather than hard clipping.

author: JustinLeu
content: Take your pick of overdone saturation…spectre? Ozone tape with a band at 10k +

author: JustinLeu
content: Hard to say without hearing what your working on, but toms can be really easy to blend with the rest of the kit! EQ+Saturation/Gate+Comp to taste...blend them in. The biggest thing is to check polarity...any changes to HP filters in the drums and you're going to need to check again (unless it is obviously better/worse when you move the HP)

I mix to the point it’s all sounding good to me without the final limiter on. Once it’s feeling like a mix, I’ll pop on my Maximizer or whatever and see how just how loud I can get it before it starts lose the mojo. If I can turn it up to -7.5-8.5 LUFS, I know I’m in business. 
But I’m mixing into at least two stages of compression before that final limiter. 

Caveat, I don’t have a Grammy, but I’m happy to share some of my shit with you if you’d like to gauge whether my advice is worth taking.

content:
Kind of related to recent posts:
I watched Tezio on MWTM and I have a couple of questions regarding compression. I usually reach for a compressor, either to controlling a dynamic recording, manipulating transients and/or saturating something. 
With the kind of material in that song (Chris Brown), with exclusively programmed material (except for vocals) I was blown away that he compressed every track. (Not my “home-genre” I should say)
Is the game here handling transients, lengthening/shortening sounds? Is it more about individual sound design or aiming to get as loud as possible in the end?

author: Deleted User
content:
Some discoveries I made about compression for the past year is that the purposes you mentioned relate very much to the being able to pack more in the limited digital space (loudness) and bringing things forward and back. 

The former is more about controlling the dynamics (which includes saturating) - which is majorly about shaving off the peaks, and the latter is about transient shaping which is about front to back, how the elements dance with or against each other, and tone shaping of the individual elements themselves. And as far as I can tell and as far as my experience listening to great mixes, all of these things are common across any style except the differences are in how much it calls for and the aesthetic preferences of how each styles like to sit things dynamically. 

I’m not a mixer, so I’d be curious to see what mixers have to say about this topic.

author: Deleted User
content: A lot of synths (programmed or played/recorded) are going to need compression to keep the dynamic range from jumping too much.

author: Deleted User
content: And 808 or sub bass could benefit from lengthening. especially when you have some release time (sampler/synth) after you let go of the keys, that release can feel inflated with fast- medium release time (on a compressor)

author: Deleted User
content: same with kick drums. a lot of programmed kick drums in mid to fast tempo are going to sound better with shorter samples and length enhanced by the compression. rather than having the subby decay linger. these kick often wants to knock and snap at the same time.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
Hi @cian riordan I've been exchanging a couple of mails with Greg Norman, from Electrical Audio and I thought his response could be useful for you or any other guys here with a 351. I'm going to add that output attenuator but I'll leave the unit stock. I love the way it sounds! Now I'm curious to hear the ones modded for Electrical Audio though. Did you have the chance to hear them during the St. Vincent recording? Anyway, this is what Greg said about it:
Hello,

Yes, my typical modification will change the sound of the preamplifier. The distortion and noise is much lower when the conversion is done. If you are happy with the way yours sounds, you could simply add an output attenuator, like you say. There is a part that is popular in the DIY world for making 1176s.  It is a 3-section 600 ohm “T-pad” potentiometer. You can find it on the Capi website.  
If your unit does not currently have a 600 ohm output load resistor, you may want to add a switch to engage the attenuator. Simply having it in the circuit will load the output with 600 ohms. This might lower the headroom and change things a little bit. 

Good luck with your project,

Greg Norman

author: peterlabberton
content:
I’m not gonna dig through search or anything like that, but @M3MIYAGI, here’s what I’ve been doing for the last several years more or less (still refining/tweaking but basically the same). A lot of it stolen from @cian riordan and from this Discord, lots of wisdom from @Nomograph Mastering included.

Minimal buss compression (1-3db on loudest sections of a mix), usually some kind of tape saturation (typically Slate Virtual Tape Machine), and Pro L2. The limiter is only grabbing 3-4 dB for the most part with the odd drum hit or whatever hitting more. Rarely I’ll add in other processing to push things harder for a specific mix, but 95% of the time that’s it. Then it’s sub busses or processing on individual tracks to get the level and compression/limiting needed to get things slamming. Then for mastering I pull the gain on Pro L2 down 6 dB, print and call it a day.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
If loudness is a goal, then it's usually good to navigate that in the mix instead of waiting until mastering.

Also think it's often good to split the load across tracks vs. subgroups vs. the 2-mix, and to split the load between compression, saturation, limiting, clipping on various elements/groups/master.

Figuring out all of the above is easier with a limiter at the end.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Not a mixer but use OXF limiter often when mixers have used it. It’s very different to the usual Pro L, Ozone, Invisible, Limitless vibes. It’s more compressed feeling, crunchy in a kind of analog way. It would never be my first choice for clean loudness but if someone has mixed into it you can’t replace it with anything else

Re enhance it sounds good but I just had a record this week where the mixer used it on 100% into Ozone Maximizer and it was causing wild crackles. Enhance on its own, no crackles … Maximizer on its own, no crackles …. but the combination did. I backed off to 50% and changed limiter modes and solved while keeping the vibe. So I guess be mindful if using it heavily on the bus

"well, we turned up the 808 and the low end etc etc..." educate.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot about how I deal with resonance and unwanted harshness recently and would love to hear about how you all approach this (and maybe more broadly how you think about restraint and taste when using modern plugins). We have so many powerful tools at this point for cleaning up audio (eq, rx, soothe, spectral shaper, de-essing, etc) but when I listen closely to a lot of my favorite recordings from the last 70 years I’ll hear all sorts of weird resonances and abnormalities. 

Over time I’ve been getting better at finding a balance of how far to go with these tools and have also become aware of how easy it can be to go overboard sometimes. Beyond reps and intuition, are there things that have helped you hone in on this? And are you consciously adjusting your “threshold” based on the music or genre you’re working with or do you have a general taste for how you like to hear things regardless of the style and use other tools to get the character and vibe you’re going for.

In other words, do you think about how far you go with these tools as a creative and stylistic decision or more of a functional one?

author: Josh Bowman
content:
Oooff feel your pain that’s rough. This happens to me from time to time, not always that extreme tho.

Generally my first move is to listen while bypassing each thing and trying to identify what it’s making better and what gets worse, then if I decide to try and keep some of them I’ll attempt to move some of those plugs off the main mix buss and back onto a subgroup or instrumental buss. But no matter what it ends up with me looping sections and rebuilding the mix to match the rough vibe before I get into the actual creative fun part of the mix.

I have one producer i work with often who mixes into a comp on his all vocal buss and it’s slow and hitting like 3-6 db compression. It totally bones me while mixing so I usually end up rebalancing all the vocals section by section to match his mix before I “start mixing”. 

Sometimes I’ll just work into their buss shit and bypass the stuff/bands of each of plug that are only hurting and not helping. 

Real can of worms tbh. 

Last week I ran into the vocal buss issue- luckily it was a comp w side chain input so I did try out the sidechain, I pre fader sent all the tracks feeding it while copying automation to that send, then used a master fader to match the buss sc level to the original comps gain reduction  and it worked well in that situation and untied my hands while saving me from a whole vocal rebalance session. First time that approach ever actually worked though for me tbh. If its a comp that drums are driving into i find the sc input doesnt end up feeling the same usually.

author: vostral
content: Hello guys! I'm mixing a Trap hiphop song that i've produced. At the moment, i'm exporting the stems for a mastering engineer and a question comes up to my mind: As i playback when mixing, i'm listening to my 65 tracks all going through the mixbuss (Slate MixBus - Maag MagnumK - Bx_digital - SPL IRON - ProQ3). So the sound i'm hearing is the outcome of all the tracks being processed by this chain, and especially, compressed by the IRON compressor. So If i bounce every single track/stem individually, will they be compressed? When printinting the stems like this they would hit the bus compressor or not? Any ideas?? Thanks in advance ^^

author: Adam Thein
content:
All good it’s a little tricky at first and just really difficult to explain typed out for me.

Same concept as using a sidechain input from a kick drum to duck the 808 - an external sidechain allows us to give the compressor something to listen to and apply the compression from that source to another source.  When the kick is fed to a compressor on your 808 channel - the compressor “listens” to the kick and applies the compression curve from the kick onto the bass.

So in your case of printing stems with a mix bus compressor - you want the SPL Iron plugin to “listen” to the entire mix as it heard it before but then apply that compression to one track at a time.

We can do this in Ableton with some clever workarounds, which would be a lot more efficient to show you on a video call on the server if you are free later.  Essentially you need to print a version of your song at each point in your mix bus chain where there are dynamics plugins (just before the Slate plugin, just before the Iron Compressor but after all the other plugins) and then send that audio to those corresponding plugins’ external sidechain inputs and then you can use the “include return and master effects” and get the result you are looking for

author: shaunobi
content:
I use it and love it.

Near then end of a mix, I'll check it (in fine-grained mode, usually on the "bass heavy" curve). If I'm already sitting in the curve, I just leave it alone. If I'm a little out here and there (usually in the upper mids / highs for me) I'll put an eq (usually Weiss EQ MP or Pro Q3 - something that's not going to add "analog" saturation) right before it and make the changes it's suggesting, watching it to see if I got it close.

I think flip the EQ off and on to see if I like it more or less. Maybe half the time I DO like it more, though I often "back it off" a little, such that I'm like 50% or 70% of the way to what it's saying would be a "normal" mix.

The other ~half of the time I'm like "naw, don't like that" and disable the EQ.

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, I kind of took things for a little detour, but: I was sitting in this guys studio one day listening to tons of different tracks on his playback. Then again multiple times on his website etc. etc. I noticed this phenomenon that after listening to his tracks I would lose interest after about 30 seconds. They would sound great at first - all the tape shit and analog gear and whatnot - but I just consistently lost interest in all his tracks for whatever reason. Couldn't listen to them all the way through... Ran into him at the bar and started talking with him about compression and what compressors he uses on what and blah, blah, blah. To my surprise he's a big fan of compression and uses a lot of them at different stages - I think mostly because he has them and he can. Told me about how he'll have one taking off some and then another taking off some and then the master bus taking off some... I know this is a common technique to have different compressors taking off little bits, and one I've started to employ in the box, but I've concluded that by the time his tracks hit the master they're already pretty "smooth" and that master just takes the last edge off them - That's why I lost interest in his songs. Not dynamic enough for my ears. The end. Also, the fact that he only uses one inch tape could have something to do with it. The End.

author: earwormfarmer
content:
I’ve also been loving the unfairchild plugin and it’s great on the mixbus imo. Recently have been using it for back-bus compression, a technique I heard Andrew Scheps talk about which is basically a copy of the mixbus minus drums. Mix bus stays uncompressed or less compressed. Back bus gets compressed more aggressively than I would do a mix bus. Blend that under the mix bus to taste. Really good for locking all the instrumentation together around vocals without dynamics getting pulled around by the drums. I think Andrew uses some kind of 1176 but the idea works with all kinds of compressors.

Mix bus and backbus both feed into a 2-bus where more processing may happen. Something like Pultec EQP1q, tape emultion, Pro L2? But I like to change things up!

author: Brian Reynolds

author: Jack
content:
Going to assume you’re talking more Rumours than Aerosmith.

Drums: dbx 160, transient designer on close mics to thud things up, Fabfilter Saturns ‘dynamics’ knob works quite well to tighten things too, no slammin’ compression on room mics/overheads, sometimes hi-passing overheads into being ‘cymbal mics’ and giving the close mics their space 

Vocals: Dolby trick, not always super aggressively hi-passed, H3000/Microshift backing vocals

Guitars: acoustic 12 string layers, phasers/flangers, mid-forward drives, acoustic guitars often super hi-passed 

Bass: flatwound strings, picked 

Annoying answer: it’s mostly in the arrangement

author: bobby k
content: Some badass feedback has already been given but something I have to remind myself of every day is to focus mostly on the drum buss and mic levels/polarity. if a frequency is killing you in one mic, it’s probably in most of the others. Try EQing the buss and avoid over processing individual mics. Also, a de-esser might make a better tool than soothe for what you’re dealing with! Last thing, I’d suggest finding the mic with the best tone and building around that. sometimes people mix just the close mics and let the bleed create that glue. If you’re really up to it, you could drop the stems in a Dropbox and DM myself (or anyone else interested) to get a better idea of how “bad” it is and give more direct feedback.

author: Sei046
content:
I would definitely say the chain, say fx, pre, mic etc is almost inconsequential against the vocal performance. Every extra minute spent on trying to iron it all out there will save you hours in editing and mixing. I’ve often considered selling a piece of gear and then had a really stellar vocal go through only to realise there was nothing wrong with the gear. I’m sure you’re sick of reading it but the performance is everything. You can’t REALLY EQ air and body into a vocal that isn’t there. You can’t try simulate it alright. And you can’t create actual excitement with compression, just try and trick the brain into thinking there’s excitement. A 57 into any preamp into any interface with a stellar performance will sound amazing. 

After that is just treatment, and it’s essentially pointless discussing chains because it’s so song and vision dependant. 

A boring answer I know but you’ll save a lot of headache and heart ache the sooner you learn it. 

It’s like when you hear a new compressor plugin just explode a drum room and it sounds amazing. Analogue glue, explosive release, so much groove. And then you slap it on the lacklustre room and performance you actually have in front of you and it doesn’t seem to sound so amazing any more.

author: James Cronier
content: I wanna poll the collective here: I'm producing prog-y metal album, and I'm at the point where we have the final drum takes in. the recordings are great ! to work with em the way I want to, the close mics need to be gated very accurately. In the past I've automated the gate threshold, or made key tracks to control the gates. I've found both methods to work, and be similarly labor intensive. if you had to choose one method, which would you pick, and why?

author: cian riordan
content: If you're in pro-tools, sidechains are a constantly moving target with delay compensation, so I would always opt to just automate the gate threshold. Little more work but then its nice to be able to control the range afterwards and allow some bleed back in to help gel the drum sound.

author: Ed Sokolowski
content: I make key spikes and run them into sidechain inputs. For a while PT had a smaller limit on delay compensation on sidechains but they increased it a few years ago. I still make dummy outputs for the key tracks which seems to keep the delay compensation updated and happy, never have issues these days. I love being able to use the spikes to put my gates anywhere in the chain, or to key compressors/expanders/gates on reverbs or room mics etc. and my ocd is happier with consistent gating each time, as much as I dig the trigger and sonnox gates, I never 100% trust real time ones.

author: onanisland
content:
Generalizing here without context but usually a "ballad piano" to me is in the softer spectrum, so sometimes desicion making is > check stereo image to lock in perspective > use an eq or something that doesnt overally emphasise the 3-4khz range > sometimes a Vari-Mu can ride the piano really well and give the warmth - and don't overdo it, Cinematic Rooms or VSS4 reverb for a realistic-ish space placement.

For cutting more though the mix I second spectre for brightness, but I also like the harrison EQ, it has really musical curves to get it to cut through without sounding "too much"

author: vostral
content: Just saw this on IG, i'm suspicious about this, since i have read about it on our Discord that even though the low-end is not triggering the compressor, that one-band compressor would still compress the whole signal. So anyone could confirm this?

author: vostral
content: Maybe, because low-end is skipped in the detection circuit, which would make the compressor compress less, and people feel like the low-end is forgiven 😂

author: cian riordan
content: For sure. There's a reason most compressors will have some sort of HPF side chain adjustment. This is not a groundbreaking concept.

author: JustinLeu
content:
You could achieve the same numerical amount either way (no HPF or with HPF), the threshold would be different....but the same amount of compression is possible. 

What would be VERY different is how the compressed signal "feels" 

Think about what would happen if you keyed (side-chained) your mixbus compressor with the bass guitar vs if you keyed the compressor with just the snare drum. Given the same attack/release settings the entire mix would move differently.

author: cian riordan
content: Looks like a transient shaper. The attack and sustain knobs will do just that — save you using compression for the same trick (usually these are just wave shapers). No idea what the mojo button does but I bet it’s adding some sort of harmonic saturation.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Hard clip of drum transients is an essential tool here when going for max stun. I definitely dislike the overuse of the soft clip paradigm in mixing though, it ends up giving impressive but brawny/dumb vibes. Hard to describe but I find it unmusical vs tasteful compression/limiting/subtle wave shaping to get similar impact. It might win in a quick A/B but to my ear doesn’t have the long term listenability

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Balance, pan and faders are your best friends here as Josh and Spectrum advised - this may mean getting a really good static balance or it may mean using automation to get the overall shape/macro dynamics of the mix in check.  Having been down this road many times I would forget about references at first and just get a musical balance based on the music which is actually in the DAW. Then make sure you do a 'Save as' and then start maybe adding basic EQ and compression to some elements, and just keep chipping away.  They can be tough but very rewarding projects where the upside is that you get to really maximise learning/skills!

author: spectrummasters
content:
Q for the gang , I’d be interested on hearing any strategies re : 
How do you handle a mix where the lead vocal is consistently powerful from the first verse, but the band’s dynamics follow a quiet verse/loud chorus structure?

Pulling the vocal down in the verse to match the band makes the chorus feel off, since the singer didn’t actually sing at a different level  in either section I had this situation for the last project I just finished and ended up splitting the (needed ) difference on level for the vocal between sections and adding saturation in the chorus, which worked — but I’d love to hear how others approach this kind of mismatch in vocal vs. band dynamics

author: spectrummasters
content: Thanks Chris , cool ideas . To clarify , sorry if it was unclear , I’ve finished the mixes and everyone’s happy . I went for subtly lower level in the verse and then level up slightly in the choruses with more parallel distressor . It seemed to mitigate . But I was thinking about if I come across it again . With this band I hope to produce for them moving forwards and would hope to be able to subtly encourage the vocalist to come back off the mic a bit and a little less power in appropriate sections ….. but I’m thinking  I’ll get a similar thing again from other bands .

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Oh interesting - For some reason my journey has led to me only reaching for the CLA76 on a parallel for the bass, but I should try it again in other contexts.

In case anyone would wanna try my approach to getting bass to play nice across more speakers / phones:

- I use the 20 ratio bluey to squash a bass parallel. Then I drive it through the free TSC 808 plugin for further emphasize the harmonics the bluey brings out. (EQ too)
- Then, I use Audreio on the master to play the mix through my phone instead of my monitors. Once on the phone, you can blend the parallel with the bass in a way where there’s little to no audible difference on a monitor, but the illusion of a bass can be heard through the harmonics playing on the phone.
- It’s a balancing act, but there’s almost always a nice sweet spot to be found where it doesn’t change the quality of the sound enough to be intrusively perceived on HD speakers, while giving life to the bass on lesser speakers.

This has helped my bass translate to more systems, and is the only time I find myself wanting to use the CLA76.

author: nachomaquieira
content: It all depends on the recording, the genre, how much dynamic range it needs, and whether it's competing with other elements. When I’m going for something transparent, I usually go with the ToneProjects Unisum on the insert, hitting just the louder peaks very gently, 1, 2, 3dB max. Then I add a subtle parallel comp (just as much as it helps) using something more aggressive, the SSL G Bus Comp often works great for that, also like the la2a if a slowerish releases fits into the song.

author: wcalebparker

I have both - haven’t done a deep dive but they sound a little different to me.

Drum gate is more tweaky and gives you some cool options (changing the length and frequency of the resonance - leveling out hits etc.)

I reach for silencer a lot though. It’s fast and sounds good. The kick and snare attack time isn’t always right and isn’t adjustable (not sure if there’s lookahead and I LIVE for lookahead), but it usually is a good fit for well recorded toms for me.

author: revolution
content:
anyone want to have a chat about **clip gaining vocals** in a beginner friendly way?

I recently cold DMd some random discord artists who sent me a few things to be able to practice mixing. Im totally new to doing any kind of intentional or thorough mixing. I got back beginner stuff (hip hop) and so far only two track projects,;so I'm primarily focused on vocal clean up, mix, and production. 

I have a vocal that is loud and energetic but I believe was recorded too close to the mic (or too loudly). I cleaned up the take in RX as best I could and did some slight de-clipping on the really bad peaks. I've imported it back to PT, and took some of the basic tips from the podcast notes into consideration. I want to clip gain the vocal and try to even it out without being transformative or destructive of the performance, but still taking enough liberties to improve it and learn something.

author: revolution
content:
I already had the instinct myself to use clip gain a good bit when I record my friend or demos for my friend, so I was excited to get the validation about how useful/important this can be (especially for weaker performers), but thinking of how to holistically do it with the intention of prepping the vocal is causing a bit of overthink perhaps. There's also the question of more granular clip gain for de-essing or plosives, etc., that makes me wonder what would be overdoing it or what is even needed and how to judge that.

Usually any "mixing" or editing I do is related to ideas I create or am part of capturing and have vision/inspiration and get some level of enjoyment out of it. This inspiration usually provides intention or some direction even in my ignorance. In this case I'm completely detached and uninspired essentially, while this makes me more objective, I have a hard time hearing where I want to take the vocal. 

I would appreciate some perspective and insight into the granular thought process one might take with the source material I have, having more experience and know-how. I will push through on my own and seek out feedback that way as well, but some live soundboarding would be nice. I appreciate you regardless if you read this and if you have any input at all. ty!!

If you are interested in listening or discussing it, ping or DM me. We could chat about it in vc and I could stream. Thanks again, I hope good discussion can come of this in a way that is granular or useful for curious beginners.

author: revolution
content: I def feel that. It's more so I wonder what the mindset and thought process might be on a technical level. I actually think it's a benefit to me that I'm not working with professional level work, since ultimately I want to learn how to improve my friend's music and my own recordings. I'm just the type of person that usually is able to articulate and understand what I want to do and why. I'm curious about what someone with experience might have as a raw reaction or approach. I will definitely seek out more pointed feed back after I have a larger body of work under me, but I'm also open to guidance and collaboration.

author: revolution
content:
There are definitely more technical aspects I could ask about or seek help with, like using limiters and compressors in focused and appropriate ways. Another potential hurdle in the case of working with something so raw is doing the vocal production from the ground up and making creative and technical choices on that end. 

I surely have to put in my time shooting from the hip but I'm actively looking for collaboration online and in person/studios to try to close that knowledge gap and get creative help translating my thoughts into execution on a technical level. But yes I agree that it is that simple and that generally is my approach to everything. I trust my own taste and curation but a more laser focused level, I don't think I have the experience or ear to even be sure about what I'm hearing or how to get to what I'm hearing in my head every time.

author: revolution
content:
Do you think it would be more beneficial to try to get something that is closer to a high quality recording and song early on? I'm the type to bite off more than I can chew, but I usually don't mind the consequences of that. I actually have another song from a different artist that is much better, maybe I'll start with that. To be fair my question was very open ended since in reality I'm also just wondering how to approach a vocal chain and vocal production beyond simply copying a preset or blindly adjusting settings on various plug ins. Something like an eq, or even other things like saturation or simple sidechain on a reverb is simple enough to somewhat understand, but the culmination of various settings and layered effects does start to get complicated and a bit unintuitive.

I think fundamentally I need more attempts and practice struggling on my own, but I also think it's helpful to see if at some point I can find a bit of guidance or collaboration to accelerate my learning and focus my vision and efforts more efficiently. I appreciate your response and will try to not overthink it and focus mainly on leveling the bars to taste and moving on to practice some tuning on the vocal after. Thanks again !

author: spectrummasters
content:
FWIW imho : Is there not more to the engineers duties than functionalist efficiency ? Outwith speed and minimum resources … engineers also are required to experiment and test , breeding innovation and new discovery . 

Sometimes the long windy road , the wrong path , the over engineered bridge becomes the inspiration upon which great new designs are refined . 

I suppose im advocating for mavericks . This is what I love about the impression I have of EV . The way he laughs about how many different “bridge designs “ he’s going to try . For the love and for the art . His audio naut idea  . We imho don’t need more of what we already have in record making , with its current efficient brilliance imho . That aesthetic is dialed in and well served . 
I sense people are ready for something different in the conversations I hear amongst friends and colleagues and also amongst young people
