author: Jonathan Jetter
content: The risk of the upward compression IMO is the internal note-to-note motion it creates over a shorter time scale, and the de-emphasis of transients and impact. Even if it technically only affects low-level signal, practically it has too much of an effect on the loud notes for me.

author: bobby k

author: cameron
content: Hi there, new here 🙂 🖐️ I’ve been getting more into mixing lately, especially trying to understand transients better. A lot of stuff online focuses on transient shapers, but those are mostly just volume tweaks. What I’m noticing when I’m sound-designing is that transients also feel super tied to little bits of pitch movement. Like, if I make a kick with a soft pitch sweep, it hits way less, but if the pitch shift is more obvious, it feels way punchier. I also saw a video showing that Skrillex snare trick: duplicate the snare, pitch up an octave, chop it so only the short transient stays, then layer it back on top. And yes it slaps. So what do you think about that? If you use a transient shaper to change the shape of a sound over time and then compress it again to tame peaks, what’s really the point? Sorry if that sounds basic, I’m still learning 🙏

author: Alex Gamble
content:
Soothe is an interesting one. Much like how every plugin manufacturer has their version of classic pieces (1176, LA-2A, 1073, etc), now we're starting to see every plugin manufacturer have their version of someone else's plugin! I can't think of any other examples off the top of my head.

I agree with the previous posts, a resonance supressor is useful and a must-have in the toolkit, but extremely easy to overuse. Don't get too caught up in the marketing hype that these will solve all your mix problems. That said, sometimes it's just what the doctor ordered.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Update on my UAD woes (since everyone's been on the edge of their seats). It took a Saturday afternoon and a lot of waiting for things to load, and I'm not sure which step actually fixed it but here's everything I did, just in case it helps someone:

- Updated from Mac OS Monterey 12.4 to the final iteration 12.7.6 
- Uninstalled all UAD software using their uninstall process as prescribed on the UAD site
- Reinstalled UA Connect (latest) and reinstalled everything. 

My missing plugs were still fucked at this point so...

- Deleted UA connect and downloaded a legacy version with confirmed compatibility with OS 12.7.6. It immediately auto updated itself anyway.
- Used the Uninstall buttons per plugin within UA connect, then reinstalled

Still no joy

- Closed Cloud Session in iLok License Manager
- Reopened Cloud Session

Nothin'

- Deleted iLok License Manager and all attendent prefs etc
- Installed latest  ilLok License Manager

Still nothin' 

- Manually deleted all of the .aax UA plugins in my PT plugins folder
- Hit the uninstall button per plugin in UA Connect to reveal the Install button again
- Installed all plugins again

Finally got the bastards working!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
The first time it happened, I discussed the options with my doctor who informed me that there is always a small chance of perforation of the ear drum with any of these processes. The water squirty thing has the highest chance, followed by manual tweezing, followed by microsuction. 

The microsuction device is like a tiny hoover, whose reach into the ear canal is limited by a larger apparatus that goes into the ear first and restricts the hoover.

author: kalpipal
content: If you're talking heavy mix bus compression: if you can use an external side chain on your bus comp (and it isn't already being used), I'd create a sidechain bus and send every single relevant track/bus to it **pre-fader** at the track's approximate level (trying to get pre-fader send level to match post-fader so the sum total drives the comp the same way as it would in the mix.)

author: cian riordan
content: If you're going into a compressor with a fixed threshold, then you're going to have to drive the input hotter to see GR. If it has a variable threshhold, then it wont really matter given there's likely a makeup gain stage.

author: cian riordan
content: If you're going into a Tape emulation or a saturation plugin, then you probably want to go a lot lower than 0dBFS unless you really want to distort your mix.

author: N
content:
I understand the perspective of (lufs don’t matter) however I want some consistency amongst my songs AND to be sufficiently loud compared to others.

I am competent of achieving very loud mixes however the introduction of artifacts bothers me. Usually I’m low passing with ISOL8 to listen for limiting/clipping clicks. These artifacts are unable to be heard unless I have a low pass filter active but I theorize that they, along with the extreme compression subconsciously degrade the listening experience by discretely assaulting your ears to the point of needing to take a break from listening. 

My music can be related sonically to clara la sans “another night” give or take more or less busy. (Keep in mind her stuff is cranked to the point of audible artifacts sitting around -7ish lufs integrated across the chorus).

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus. Leaving headroom means I can introduce less artifacts at the cost of having to squeeze the dynamic range of individual instruments more than otherwise.

My issue is that If I want to aim for let’s say -8LUFSi across the chorus in a relatively clean way with minimal artifacts, I’m forced to squeeze the mix to -7.

I’d love to hear y’all thoughts on whether or not technically inaudible artifacts/distortion matter and whether or not it’s really worth for me to squeeze my mix 2db more in the name of competitive loudness?

Ps. Please bear with me as I am trying to figure this all out solo. Feel free to criticize my approach.

author: Slow Hand
content: Just tried it - and yep - this thing rules. First thing I did was drop it on a lead vocal, pull the threshold all the way down, do a little makeup gain and it does exactly what it's supposed to do. Clear as day.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Spec Craft was immediately noticeable and a positive improvement. I didn't even need to adjust the starting preset. I just pulled the threshold down.

A/B'ing my vocal it's a maybe a little thin, but - again - I have the threshold all the way down. So I can split the difference. It's not a bad thin, either. It's just different. It's that Louis Bell pop vocal thin. So I imagine once the word gets around people are gonna dig it.
